Ottawa, May 9, 1924.

Sir,

I have to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan has arranged with the Department of Education for the Province of Manitoba for the attendance and tuition of the Indian children of the Moose Lake Reserve at the Moose Lake white school. A competent teacher has been secured to begin duties after the summer holidays. This Department is allowing a tuition grant at the rate of $20.00 per capita, per annum, based on the average attendance as shown by returns which should be prepared by the teacher at the end of each quarter and forwarded by you for transmission to the Department.

You should, upon the occasion of your next visit to Moose Lake, encourage the Indian parents to take advantage of the facilities offered for the education of their children so that there will be a regular attendance of the children of school age. The teacher should include on the quarterly returns for submission to this Department only the names of Indian children. When forwarding these returns, please state the name of the Secretary-Treasurer of the school board to whom cheques in payment for the tuition grant should be sent. We have informed His Lordship of the tuition grant that will be allowed for the Indian children.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas,
MAN.
DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, WINNIPEG.

May 21, 1924.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I have your favour of the 9th instant advising that you have been informed by His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan that Moose Lake School District No. 1698 will have its school in operation from September last next. I do not know where His Lordship got this information or why he is so anxious to see the school in the matter. The school is in operation now and has been in operation for several years past. We have agreed to work in conjunction with the diocese if a qualified teacher is furnished but thus far they have not been able to recommend a teacher to us.

We are glad to note that your Department is prepared to make a tuition grant of $20.00 per capita per annum, based on the average attendance, for any Indian children that attend the school. It may be possible to secure the attendance of some children whose parents do not wish them to go to the residential Indian schools.

Yours truly,

Sgd. R. Fletcher,
Deputy Minister of Education.

23rd March, 1925

J.W. Waddy Esq  
Indian Agent  
The Pas, Manitoba  

Dear Sir,

In reply to your favor of 18th instant, I find credits amounting to $61.54 have come forward from the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa and a cheque for this amount will be forwarded to Rev. C.J. Waite at Moose Lake.

I am very glad indeed to know that matters are going well at the school and the children making good progress.

I presume you will advise the Department of Indian Affairs to forward future payments direct to Rev. Mr. Waite.

Yours truly,

R. Fletcher  
Deputy Minister of Education.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6240, file 526-3, part 1)
Sir;-

I have the honor to enclose return for March quarter 1925 from the teacher of the Day School at Moose Lake.

The salary allowed him by the Manitoba Government is half that paid other teachers, and the grant from the Department I think should be paid direct to Mr. Waite. When the school was reopened I understood that the Manitoba Government was to pay his full salary and to receive our grant back into their hands; however this was not correct. The Manitoba Government are in favor of allowing the teacher to receive our grant.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

In reference to the Combined Wite and Indian Day School at Moose Lake, Man., I beg to state that the teacher Rev. Mr. Waite moved away to another district last summer.

A Rev. Mr. Parker has been appointed as Missionary at Moose Lake, his wife who is a teacher having been appointed by the Manitoba Government to be the teacher of the above school.

Mrs. Parker has taught the Indian children during September and I enclose a report she handed to me, it can be dealt with as Department decides. I also enclose requisition for school material for this school.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 8, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, informing the Department that owing to the illness of Mrs. Parker, teacher of the Moose Lake Combined Indian and White Day School, her husband has received permission from the Provincial Department of Education to substitute as teacher until the end of the present month.

In reply I beg to say that this Department will also approve of the Rev. Mr. Parker substituting during the illness of his wife. We note that the cheque in payment of his services is to be forwarded, as formerly, to Mrs. Parker.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, April 4th, 1929.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, informing the Department that owing to sickness the combined white and Indian school at Moon Lake has not been in operation during the quarter ending March 31st, last, also that the teacher has obtained permission from the Department of Education, Winnipeg, to take leave of absence to May 31st, next.

With reference to the deduction by the Church authorities of the amount of salary paid Mrs. Parker from that of her husband's salary who is missionary on the Reserve, I have to say that this Department does not feel that it can take any action in this matter. The appointment of the teacher is made by the provincial authorities, and this Department only allows a grant based on the average attendance. The question of placing any Indian children of school age in residential schools would receive favourable consideration if the present arrangements for the carrying on of the combined day school are unsatisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Ottawa, August 3, 1932.

Sir:

I have to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Brandon has nominated the services of Mr. Harold Newton to succeed Mr. Lumb, who has resigned, as teacher of the Moose Lake Conibear Indian and Indian Day School. His Lordship is being informed that the appointment of a teacher for this school is made by the provincial authorities and that we only allow a grant for the Indian children at the rate of $75 per teaching month, less 10 percent for the current fiscal year. His Lordship is also being advised to take up the matter of the salary of the teacher with the Deputy Minister of Education for the Province of Manitoba. He is being informed that insofar as the Department is concerned, the appointment of Mr. Newton, who holds a second class professional certificate, would be satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER DATED NOV. 28, 1940, FROM
MR. R. A. HOEY, SUPT. OF WELFARE & TRAINING,
TO RIGHT REV. W.W.H. THOMAS, D.D., BRANDON, MAN.

- Original on No. 128-6-1 -

Re Moose Lake Combined School.

A return, giving the names of the Indian children only, should be forwarded at the end of December, March and June to Indian Agent Lovell. He will certify it and forward it to the Department. In the event of the 6 children attending we will allow an amount of $15.00 a teaching month toward the salary of the teacher.

IN A LETTER TO MR. THOMAS LAMB, MOOSE LAKE, DATED JANUARY 7, 1941, MR. HOEY STATES AS FOLLOWS:

Mr. Lovell, in a letter to the Department dated October 18, 1940, intimated that in his judgment the Moose Lake School would be unable to accommodate any Indian pupils. Mr. Lovell adds: "There will be over 50 half-breed children going to school, which will make it overcrowded without the attendance of any Indian children." In view of this information from the agent that the space available in the school was required for the accommodation and instruction of half-breed children, we decided to make a small grant of $15 a month to defray the instructional costs of 4 or 5 Indian pupils who might be enrolled at the school.

Now that the attendance appears to be approximately 11, there is no reason why an adjustment of the grant cannot be made. You tell us in the last paragraph of your letter not to offer a white man 50¢ a day and board himself. I must emphasize again that the teacher of this particular school is not employed by this Department, nor have we assumed any responsibility for his appointment or for his teaching services. We are simply paying a grant to defray the cost of a small number of Indian pupils who may attend the Moose Lake School. The instruction of so-called half-breed children is wholly and in a very absolute sense the responsibility of the Provincial Government.
Memorandum:

MISS DAVIS

When the returns are received from the Moose Lake School please see official letters of November 28, 1940, before making any payment.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The school house at the time of my visit was cold and miserable, the children were huddled around the stove for warmth, nothing has been done to this building in the way of repairs, nor any attempt to make it comfortable since last year, further than a coat of whitewash given the building last August. Ottawa, February 22, 1912.

Very Reverend Sir,

Mr. Indian Agent Fischer reports to the Department that on his recent visit to the Moose Lake School he found the children huddled around the stove for warmth. He further states that nothing has been done to this building in the way of repairs or any attempt to make it comfortable since last year. The building requires replastering, storm windows and some repairs to the porch.

The Department would like you to see that these repairs are made during next summer if the school is to be continued in the building, otherwise the Department will have to withdraw the grant for rental.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

He is much interested in the work, desires the welfare of the Indians, & anxious to acquire & apply the best methods of teaching, & has the approval of the Indians.

MOOSE LAKE PUBLIC SCHOOL.

This is a combined White and Indian school. It is under the Provincial Government, and the Indian Department pay $25.00 per capita for each Indian child in attendance.

Mrs. Parker is the teacher in charge. She holds her Second Class Professional and is doing splendid work. The Indian children present numbered 12, there being 5 boys and 7 girls. In addition to these there were 16 other pupils. The grades range from one to four.

The building is a frame structure and is badly in need of paint, both inside and out.

The classroom was tidy and all the children appeared clean and fairly well clothed.

I found the outside windows all on and the transoms above the windows nailed shut. I spoke to Mrs. Parker about this and she said it was very difficult to get anyone to do work about the school. I pointed this out to the Indian Chief and asked him to arrange with the fire ranger, who is the trustee, to see that the windows are fixed so that plenty of fresh air may be obtained.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that I paid Treaty at Moose Lake on June 4th, as per schedule.

Albert Stagg old Chief resigned. Held election and ballot revealed a majority of one in favor of Philip Tobacco over Jacob Nasecapow. Declared Tobacco Chief. Instructed him in his new duties as per Indian Act.

A number of matters were discussed and settled. After Doctor's visit to gouses he reported no sickness.

The school belongs to the Provincial Govt. who furnished paint to paint the building. The Indians volunteered to do the work free, but asked me to request four windows 48 x 48, 20 lbs of 3" nails and a small amount of grub for the work.

Potatoes and garden seeds all planted and doing fine.

There is an island in Moose Lake on which there is some very good Spruce timber, and the Indians would like to dispose of it. It would be necessary to look the timber over before passing an opinion on the matter.

Two cases of destitution were visited, and Special Rations asked for. John Miles 85 years of age and alone, also Jane Pashenose is in the same condition.

All of which I submit for your approval.

Mr. Christianson's Report on Schools in The Pas Agency:

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honor to report that while in The Pas Agency recently, installing the new Acting Indian Agent there, I visited and inspected the Moose Lake Indian Day School and the McKay Indian Residential School.

MOOSE LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL,

The building is just off the edge of the Reserve and is the property of the Provincial Government.

At the present time the school is being taught by Mr. F. Lumb. I am quite sure that this young man is very much interested in his work, and he has the proper qualifications, having had normal training as well as having previously taught at the Gordon's Residential School.

There are 25 children on the register, and on the day of my visit, which was very stormy, there were 17 present,—12 Indian and 4 Halfbreed children. I might say there is quite a Halfbreed settlement adjoining this Reserve. Grades I to IV are being taught at this school at the present time.

This being the first time I have visited this school I do not know what progress the children have made, but I am quite sure that the present teacher will meet with splendid results if he remains there.

I do not know what the arrangement is between the Department and the Province of Manitoba, but as I have stated above

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
REGINA.
MOOSE LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL, (Cont'd).—

stated above, the building is owned by the Government and was no doubt built to enable the halfbreed children to get an education. However, I presume that at the time the building was erected, some agreement was entered into between the Manitoba Government and the Department of Indian Affairs. The building itself is in a fair state of repair, and last summer it was painted inside and out by the Indians and the trader who lives right near the school, the paint having been furnished by the Provincial Government. There were several panes of glass broken and the holes patched up. The desks were in very bad shape, but these could be fixed up with very little difficulty. However, a new stove is very urgently required in this school, the sides of the one now in use having caved in from long use and over-heating. The hinges are broken off the door, and it would be practically useless to repair this, as the front is also burnt out. It will be readily seen that it is very difficult to keep the building warm with a stove of this kind. Moreover, it is not safe to put on a very big fire. Not knowing what the arrangement is I cannot say whose place it is to furnish the stove, but in any event, the McLary's Camp Comfort Wood Burning Stove would meet their requirements satisfactorily.

Dear Sir,

I would like to call your attention to the school building of the Moose Lake Day School.

The building is in very bad condition, quite a number of windows are broken and other repairs needed. The teacher, the Rev. A. Scrase, spent $30.00 recently, out of his own funds to purchase lumber and material for desk and forms. He wrote to me to see if there was no way in getting a refund of this expenditure.

I wrote to the Provincial Department of Education about the matter and they refused to do anything about the repairs, as they stated they paid part of the teacher's salary and it was the trustees duty to keep the building in repair. The school is in an unorganized territory and there does not seem to be any method of taxation arranged for school purposes, consequently there is no money available for repairs.

There are about 15 Indian children attending this school, a number of half-breeds and one or two white children. I am anxious to get the building repaired and keep it in repair, as the condition it is in now, is bound to affect the health of the Indian children. I would like to know what action I can take to get these repairs done.

Sir,

I have the honor to state that during the past summer a day school has been established among the Indians at Nelson House, in the Territory of Keewatin. I am aware that this place is outside of Treaty limits, but it is one of those necessitous and somewhat exceptional cases which sometimes receive aid from the Department. For some years past the Indians at this point have been asking very earnestly that a school might be established, and the Missionary in charge, the Rev Mr Gaudin, has strongly supported the application. Desiring to have all possible information before taking action the Rev Mr McDougall was instructed to enquire and report the facts in the case. Early last summer he visited Nelson House, and as a result of his enquiries a qualified teacher was obtained and sent out. I trust that the Department will place this school on the list to receive the customary aid, and that instructions may be sent to the Commissioner to forward the blank forms and registers for the use of the teacher.

OTTAWA, 13th November, 1899

The Secretary:

Rev. Dr Sutherland's letter of the 10th instant herewith asks for a grant for school which has recently been established by the Methodist Missionary Society at Nelson House in the Territory of Keewatin. Nelson House is, as Dr Sutherland states, outside of treaty limits and no provision is made for a Methodist school at that place. The Census return for '98 shows that there are 115 Roman Catholic Indians in the neighborhood of Nelson River, the numbers of other denominations and pagans not being given.

The Church of England receives a grant of $200.00 for each of six schools in the Diocese of Wessex, which embraces the district around Hudson's Bay.

This is the first application that has been received from the Methodist Church for a school in this locality and the Department has no information as to the number of Indians claimed by them as being of their faith, nor of the number of children of school age.

The amount of the grant given day schools outside treaty limits is limited to $200.00

I think the Department should be furnished with further information on the above points before it can fully consider this application.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 16th ultimo, No. 191433, respecting the school recently established by the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church at Nelson House, I beg to say that in a letter received some time ago, from the Rev Mr Gaudin, missionary at Nelson house, he informs me that there are some 80 children of school age, and a host of little ones growing up; of these about 20 usually remain near enough to attend school a good deal of the time, and for the others at least something could be done during the summer." He further points out that if provision could be made at the Mission for from 10 to 20 of the children whose parents go to the woods during the autumn and winter, quite a large school could be maintained during the year.

I cannot at the moment give the exact number of Indians connected with the Mission, but a number of years ago more than 300 had identified themselves with the Methodist Church, and there has been considerable increase since that time.

I can readily see that there are difficulties in the way of securing a grant from the Department where application is made in the middle of the year; but I have understood that it is within the authority of the Department to meet special cases out of unexpended balances that have been voted by Parliament for the Indian work. The need of a school at Nelson House was so great that the Rev
John McDougall, when visiting that point last summer, promised them a teacher without delay. If under these circumstances the Department can make a proportionate grant for the current year it will be much appreciated.

It might not be out of place to add that we are expending annually upon the Indian work over $42,000 in addition to what is received from the Indian Department, and about one-fourth of this amount is expended in the educational work.

Sir,

We have the honor to inform you that Mr. John Simmons, Inspector of Indian Agencies, has just visited us as a representative of the Government, bringing us the information that in the very near future we may expect an offer of treaty negotiations from the Government at Ottawa, and whereas we are given to understand that when such time of treaty shall be arrived into, one clause shall be educational, we as a band assembled in council deem it wisdom on our part to petition the Government through the Department of Interior with regard to the kind of school most suitable to the requirements and needs of our people.

We therefore advance the following reasons in favor of the establishment of a boarding school amongst us:

1. The work done in the past in our day-schools has...
been faithful. But in the face of the best efforts, the Day School has proven and continues to prove a most inefficient factor from an educational standpoint. The school has been centrally located but this is of very little real assistance. The dwellings are so scattered and scattered over so great an area that the nearest children can reach the school only with great difficulty and much hardship. Many days it is utterly impossible for them to reach school at all.

II. The school cannot be kept open throughout the year. It is only in the winter months that school is at all possible. Small children are not to be allowed to cross the lake in bark canoes.

III. There is but a very small percentage of the children who are of school age who are here during the months that school is open. The fathers are all hunters; their hunting-grounds are many miles away and they take their entire families with them. To these children especially (over 125 children) the Boarding School will be a boon.
When winter sets in the parents can change to their hunting-grounds leaving their children behind. When summer comes again the children and parents could once more be together for the holiday weeks.

II. We would feel no necessity to call upon any other neighboring bands to furnish children since we can from our own families furnish at least one hundred school age.

I. The Canadian Northern Railway is constructing a branch line from Edmonton to Fort Churchill. This survey line runs close to Nelson House. One is only about ten miles distant and the second is about forty. Indications at present point toward the use of the main line. When that road comes through the question of transport of supplies becomes a matter for easy settlement.

The above statement of our case we humbly present for your careful consideration making not when Treaty is entered into by the
Government with us that no further provision be made for the education of our children through the day-school but that as soon as railway communications are opened up a Boarding School be established at this point for us.

Signed on behalf of the members of the band by

The Deputy Superintendent General:

The Chief and Councillors of the Nelson House band have written, asking that when treaty is made with them, provision should be made for the establishment of a boarding school there in lieu of day schools. They want this made one of the terms of the treaty. In all previous treaties the Crown simply agrees to maintain a school in each reserve set apart, whenever the Indians of the reserve shall desire it. This refers only to a day school. The Department has never yet admitted any obligation to provide boarding schools under treaty, and if an exception were made in favour of these Indians you may rest assured that all the other bands who have taken treaty would expect similar treatment.

There is considerable agitation for the extension of the boarding school system, and the assumption by the Department of the full cost of maintenance and management. It, therefore, rests with the Department to decide whether it should change the educational clause in the treaty or not. I went fully into the question of the extension of the boarding school in my memorandum of July 10, last, on Dr. Bryce's report of inspection of schools in Manitoba and the Northwest.

Sir,

The Methodist Church established their Mission at Nelson House in the year 1874 under the pastorate of the writer of this report. They have continued the work through 35 years at a cost of at least $1000.00 per year. They have therefore some right to ask for assistance when it is remembered that they must have spent $5000.00 to show their own good faith.

The Roman Catholics entered the field in the eighties but have not carried on a very vigorous or a continuous work and have paid little attention to School work. It seems only right however to mention the facts and state that they have a Church there and a considerable membership.

The population is about 400 and these may be divided in the proportion of one third Catholics to two thirds Methodist or say 150 of the former Church and 250 of the latter.

The child population numbers 235. Of these 122 are girls and 113 are boys. Admitting the two thirds ratio then the Methodist Church should claim at least 150 children.

It should be explained however that many of the Men of this Band are hunters who do not locate near the Mission or for that matter anywhere else. They are moving from one place to the other and are known as "wood Indians" men who live in tents and take their families with them and spend only a short time in summer at the H.B.Post or near one of the Mission stations. It is assumed that two thirds of the whole number are of this class and that would reduce the
Methodist School going element to about fifty (50)

It is well known that the possible attendance is never the actual attendance and making allowance for those that are "grown ups" or who are the children of non-progressive parents not in sympathy with the Schools the Methodists should be able to command an average attendance of 25 or 30.

The situation of the Methodist Mission is favorable to attendance especially in winter as it is about midway between the "Fort" on the one side and the "Ootawain" on the other. In summer canoes must be used and the difficulty would increase but a considerable number tent on the hills near by so that a sufficient number of children would be always near, who could walk to School.

There are about 15 houses within a radius of three miles from the Mission and the locality is favorable for the erection of a School building.

I am persuaded that the only kind of building that could be erected would be one of logs. Lumber cannot be freighted into the country. The expense would be so high that no one would recommend it. A few boards for floors and ceilings might be made by means of a whip saw. Logs might be procured at a distance of from 4 to 6 miles. Labor is cheap about one dollar a day being the rate of wages. If shingles were used they would have to be bought on Lake Winnipeg and moved down at great expense (9.00) per 100 lbs so that Mica Roofing would be best. Nails would also have to be bought in Selkirk and freighted down in the York boats of the H.B.Company.

As to the cost of building at Nelson House I think an approximation might be made as follows:

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| Procuring Logs        | 100.00 |
| Sawing Boards         | 100.00 |
| Erecting Building     | 200.00 |
| Doors windows nails   | 30.00  |
| Mica roofing freight etc | 70.00 |
| **Total**             | **500.00** |
As to the party to build the School

The Hudson Bay Company at Norway House Mr C.C.Sinclair might undertake the work. It is no reflection on the Methodist minister now in charge to say that he is inexperienced and not practical for he is quite young and this is his first charge.

The Rev Mr Ferrier might send in a man with skill enough to complete such a work but high wages would be charged and the Company is rather averse to strangers entering the best fur bearing part of their territory as it gives undue prominence to their business.

I do not know any person at Nelson House whom I could recommend as a suitable builder but the Agent at Norway House could procure men and control the expense and this is probably the wise course to pursue. Let the Agent send reliable men down to put the building in shape for practical use.

I would suggest in conclusion that the bark be removed from the logs and that the corners be dove-tailed.

I have the honor to be

Nelson House, Day School, Norway House Agency, January Report, 1913.

Teacher,- Rev. Henry T. Wright.

This school has been closed for many reasons, about the last of March all the Indians leave the village, first Spring, then they return for a few weeks, until treaty is paid, then the men work in boats for the Hudson's Bay Co., the women and children all leave for the fishing grounds, returning, just long enough to take their fall outfit, then they all leave here, some return, about the first of November, and others not until near Xmas. By this you will see that the teacher is left alone on the reserve over half the time.

School opened on Monday, January 20th, 1913.

Attendance,- There are 45 pupils on the roll, 16 boys and 29 girls. The children live far from the school, attendance is very irregular, and everything but punctual. The children are all clean and well clothed.

School is held in the church, which is far too large, requiring two stoves to make it comfortable. The school building is in bad repairs making it unfit for school purposes.

Progress, all pupils are in standard 1, a few can add to a hundred, and the rest are at the A, B, C's, etc.

Fuel,- The Indians are very slow about getting wood, the teacher in years past has supplied over half the fuel required. The Chief tries to do his part but the Indians only laugh at him, and fail to help us in our work. At present time we have wood enough for at least a week, perhaps ten days.
No 2

The school children without an exception have the itch, this has been in our midst for the past year, and is on the increase.

In closing this monthly report, I wish to express my sincere thanks to Mr J. G. Stewart, our agent, who on every occasion has shown a very favourable interest in our school work, and the good of the Indians on this Reserve,

Respectfully submitted,

I am,

Yours faithfully,

H.T. Wright

March 24, 1919

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have almost finished seven years work among the Cross Lake and Nelson House Indians. One year at Cross Lake and six years at Nelson House.

I am feeling the nervous strain of my work and need change after such an isolated life. I am leaving here the first of June for a year rest and change.

I heard word from the Secretary of the W.M.S. of the Methodist Church saying they were trying to find a suitable worker to take up my work when I leave, so feel sure it is their interest.
To continue the work I have started at Nelson House.

If they fail to secure a suitable worker who would be willing to live in such an isolated spot, I have signified my willingness to return at the end of my furlough health permit.

In the meantime Mr. Butty will act as medical Dispenser as he is by all Accounts the most suitable person living here.

My Interpreter and assistant who has worked with me for six out of the six years I have been here, and is very useful among the Indians, so that altogether the people will be better looked after than before I came.

I would like to thank you for your kind consideration in continuing the grant of $75.00 to assist in feeding my dogs throughout the year etc.
In the present time,
It has been a great help.
I would also like to mention the kind consideration shown me by all the Indian Department's Officials that I have had business connected with; they have shown a kindly interest in my work, and readily assist in any way that was helpful.

I have enjoyed my work among the Nelson Reserve Indians, have found them kind and grateful for assistance given.

I believe they are the most healthy band of Indians I have met in my thirty-two years of service.

I am very sincerely yours,

(Miss) A. B. Jackson
Missionary Nurse.

Dear Sirs:

I am writing your department on behalf of the Nelson House Band. They have taken up with me, asking me to communicate with you, the matter of a Boarding school at their reserve, for the children of that district instead of the day school as heretofore.

They think that a Boarding school would be in every way more satisfactory than the day school, because the Indians are away all winter trading and trapping and consequently their children are none of them able to attend the day school. So very few are available to attend the day school during the winter months that the expense of keeping the day school open is quite useless, whereas if a Boarding school were in operation all the children on the reserve and in the district could be at the boarding school and so receive a much needed education, all the year round.

This matter the Indians took up with the Rev. Arthur Baumer, when he was visiting the reserve this summer and meetings were called by the Indians to discuss the situation. The Indians voted unanimously in favor of a Boarding school, and to do away with the Day school. They are very anxious to have the school built at once, and to have it on their reserve in a place convenient to all. They realize the importance of having their children educated and find that the day school does not in any way supply the need. They want their children well educated so that they can go out and take their place earning a livelihood among the white people and become the best of citizens.

As to location of the school they wish that, if the matter is favorably considered by your department, the school shall be built at Beaver Dam, on the Burnt Wood River. This is the most advantageous point in all that country from many points of view. There is abundant fish all the year round and extensive hay lands, and is accessible to everybody.

This letter is written today at the request of representatives of the Nelson House Band, who are here present, in The Pas Today. They desire a reply as soon as possible and would like to have action taken at once with a view to having the school built at once if favorable to your department, which they sincerely hope it will be.

They discussed this proposition with Indian Agent Waddy on his recent visit to their reserve and requested his assistance, which he is very willing to give. The matter is being taken up with him today as well as with your department by this letter.

An early reply is requested and that your reply be addressed to Chief Patrick Constant, of The Pas Indian Reserve. This because of the distance away from here of the Nelson House Reserve, and the long time taken in getting mail to and from that place. He will act as a sort of attorney for them in this matter at their request and will know what to say and do in regard to the situation when you reply.

Kindly answer as soon as possibly and oblige,

Yours Very Sincerely Etc.

Dear Mr. Scott:

The Indians of the Nelson House Reserve have been asking for years for a school to be built there and operated under the auspices of the Methodist Church. Some of them are in town here now and have been in touch with the local Indians and they are writing you a letter which I enclose herewith.

I have not seen the letter but have a fair idea of some of the contents as they have been asking me questions every day for the past week. In order to give you an idea of the present standing of matters at Nelson House I enclose my office file regards what has been done lately.

This is a mixed-up business from the start, but last week I got at the real truth of why the Methodist Church people ask for a day school when the Indians require a boarding school. Mr. Barner told me then that Senator Lougheed when Minister told the Churches that the Department did not intend in future putting up small boarding schools which would become a liability on the funds of the churches or the Department, but that the outlay in small schools and the churches were not financially fixed to pay over charges above the grant. This is the first time I had even heard of such an agreement.

In 1919 and each year after that the Indians asked for a boarding school, but I knew the funds were low and kept the matter shelved for the time being. Last year matters came to a showdown, the Indians asked that the matter be sent to the Department for a decision, so I took the question up with Mr. Ferrier at Brandon to see how the Church stood. His answer is on my file.

The Indians want something and I have been careful to keep them friendly with the Church. They know that schools are being built elsewhere and I have told them that if they get the co-operation of the church that the Department listens to their recommendations.

I firmly believe that the real solution of the school question there is a boarding school; if the time is not opportune a day school would do temporarily and any orphan could be sent to Brandon school.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Health Rules

The Fifth Rule

By Dr. J. L. BIGGAR

Many people might think that there is no need for a Health Rule about playing. Most children do not need to be told to play. They do so instinctively and enthusiastically. Sometimes they do not want to do anything else.

But there is a need for the rule, because there are children who for one reason or another are not keen about playing and especially about playing in the open air. There are several things which may cause the development of the not-playing habit. An illness may begin it, or moving from one town or school to another so that one's old friends are lost, or new friends have to be made with strangers. Sometimes when a child has no brothers or sisters, he, or more often she, prefers to help with the work at home rather than to play with other boys and girls. But the most frequent cause is too great an interest in stories so that one exciting book after another is a great deal more attractive than playing in the open air.

These are only a few of the reasons why it was thought necessary to make a rule about playing outdoors. Too many boys and girls do not get the open air exercise that they should have if they are to grow up strong and healthy. Too many grown-ups did not learn when they were young the very great importance of fresh air, sunshine and muscular activity. If they had, there would be more really strong and healthy people.

If I ask you your grandparents what was thought in their younger days about this matter, you would probably be surprised, because it is only comparatively recently that the importance of good habits in this respect has been fully realized. And the rather unfortunate thing is that just as this realization is becoming clearer all sorts of vehicles to save us from activity in the open air are becoming more and more popular. To-day nobody in the city walks if it can be avoided and even in the country people are beginning to think that children should be taken to school in cars or buses.

You may say, of course, that walking is not much of a play, and that it is a great deal nicer to go to school by street car or an automobile and save time and energy for playing. But, if you stop to think, you will see that "playing" is very hard to define and that almost everything including messages and chores, can be made into a game of some kind or another.

Not long ago a man told this story: "There were two old men," he said, "both about eighty, both rather feeble and slow but not really incapacitated by their many years. Both of them had wooden sticks in their hands and both were taking long walks over grassy places. They were doing more or less the sort of thing and each seemed to be enjoying himself. One of them had a prong on the end of his stick and with this he was picking up scraps of paper and putting them into a bag he carried on his shoulder. The other had a metal piece at the end of his stick and with this he was hitting a ball. The same sun shone on both of them and when midday came both of them were very hungry and other plain food. One was the richest man in the world playing a game of golf and the other was a park-keeper earning his living by keeping the grounds tidy."

The Rule says to play "in the open air every day." Thirty or forty years ago Mark Twain said that people were always talking about the weather but that no one had ever done anything about it. It is just as true to-day. All of us are inclined to be perpetually dissatisfied with it. Too hot, too cold, too dry or too wet, too still or too windy,—always too something. Yet it is from the weather, which gives us the open air every day, that we gain our health and vigor. Fresh air and sunshine, rain and wind, cold and heat, are God's best gifts to man.

There is no stimulant to be compared with a bright frosty morning out-of-doors. Nothing has ever been found so beneficial for our well-being as sunshine. No effort brings so happy a reward as a walk in the open air with the wind and the snow and the rain. These are the things which send the blood racing through the veins, bringing colour to cheeks and sparkle to eyes, cleansing the bones with clean firm flesh, and freeing the mind of worry and depression. Truly the weather is nature's health giver.

In Canada we are among the most fortunate of nations. Our brilliant sunshine, our hot summers and the clear sparkling cold of our winters, our open spaces where the clean wind carries the tang of our forests and waters, the ice for skating, the forests for camping, the birds of the air and the beasts of the field for studying, the flowers for finding, the trees for knowing — truly ours is a glorious climate. And, properly dressed, it is never too cold nor too hot, too wet or too stormy to play, either at games or at work, in the open air every day and by so doing, to gain health and strength and energy and vigor and happiness.
The Story of Nehemiah Teaboy

By CHARLES CLAY

This is the story of Nehemiah Teaboy of Nelson House, Manitoba, as he told it to me the other day when I went up to visit him and his mother and to buy from them a pair of moccasins to replace my old and almost worn-out pair.

I am an Indian boy. I was born thirteen winters ago in a rough log cabin that stood, along with several others, on the rocky shores of Round Lake near Kegewah Lake. It was from there, the winter rendezvous of several Indian families, that our fathers hunted and trapped.

I belong to the Muskego tribe of the Cree Indians. My name is Nehemiah Teaboy and I like it very much. The first part is from the Bible, being the name of one of the books. My grandmother's sister named it out for me when I was born. There is a story about the second part of my name and I shall tell it to you.

Long, long, long ago, when my father's father's father's father was a young man, there were no white men living in this part of the country. Of course, they had been to see my ancestors before that and to trade for the furs which they had caught, and my ancestors had travelled many days to see the strange white men, but the white men had not come to build dwellings and to live with them before. These white men came along with a trading company of men called the Hudson's Bay Company. They built big houses of logs and traded with the fur, tea, knick-knacks, guns, powder, cloth, and beads for the furs which my forefathers caught.

In summer my ancestors used to bring their dogs and all their belongings and pitch their wigwams near the Company's post; then in winter they travelled far away and trapped and hunted.

Now, in those olden days, my great-great-grandfather's name was Kekanaskaskan, which means "a quilt." The white men found this name so hard to say and to write that they changed it. My great-great-grandfather liked to drink the white men's new drink made of leaves called "tea," so the white men of those days called him "Teaboy."

The Hudson's Bay Company still have a fur trading post and my people still trade their furs to them; but things are very different now than when my ancestral name was Kekanaskaskan. Instead of old-fashioned guns, bullets and powder and shot, we have modern highpower rifles; instead of using the light of fires to see by at night, we have candles and lamps; instead of birch bark canoes, we use canoes made in a far-off factory; instead of dressing in rabbit skins in wintertime, we use woollen clothes. My people have been taken under the care of the white man's government and we have a Reserve where we can build houses. There is a church and also a school. If my great-great-grandfather saw all these things now he would be very surprised.

Our Reserve is around a large lake called Waskewasko which is away in the northern part of Manitoba. About 140 miles away is the nearest station of the new Hudson's Bay Railway. In the summertime we often go down there to see the trains and other strange sights of the white man.

When I first saw a train I was very afraid of it and ran away as fast as I could go; but when I saw that the eskototapanask didn't chase me and that the other boys and girls didn't run, I soon came back and was no longer afraid. We call the train eskototapanask, which means "fire-toboggan."

In summer, most of the Indians of this band come and live on the Reserve. Some of them have houses; others live in wigwams. The Hudson's Bay Company's fur trading post is at the Reserve as well as the church and the school. The nearest Reserve to us is over a hundred miles away and when we go there, as well as to the "city," we have to go by canoe in summer and dog-sled in winter. There are no permanent camps along the way.

In winter, nearly all the men of this band go away to hunt and trap. Sometimes the women and children live on the Reserve, but that is not often; generally, the men take their families with them. This winter my father and one of my big brothers went away into the far north to trap the white fox. They went away by dogteams and left here last November. The white foxes live just on the edge of the Barren Lands about thirty miles north of here. Father and brother intended to build a shack just where the timber stops growing, for there are no trees on the Barren Lands. From this shack they will go out with two traps lines with about eighty traps in each. They took enough flour and tea and land clothes and ammunition last there. There are many white foxes in parts of the country which they can kill for meat. It is now the beginning of April and we have had no word from them. Father said they would be back after the first of May or month or sooner, so we expect them any time. I hope they have killed lots of foxes for there are many nice things at the Company's post that we would like to have.

My other big brother and his wife and my mother and we smaller children have lived all winter in our house on the lake which is about a mile from the school and four miles from the Company's post. Brother is feeding us until father comes back; then father will look after all of us again.

Brother whose name is Moses has a trapping up the river and around some other little lakes. I go with him when he looks at his traps. He drives a team of five dogs. I run ahead of the dogs so they will pull better. Sometimes.
we are away for two or three weeks. We take our blankets and grub and canoes and live out in the open. We dress in moose-hide moccasins and mitts. They have many pretty beads on them. I have a moose-hide coat, too, with beads on it; it is a caribou-skin made of a caribou-skin with the hair left on. These coats are short so we can run. They have hoods on them to keep our heads and faces warm and to keep the snow from falling down our necks when we make a camp in the bush. The women make the moccasins and mitts and coats for us. Next winter I am going to have a pair of moose-skin trousers, too; I have to shoot the moose first.

There are seventy-five traps in my brother's trapline. We have caught several foxes, some mink, many weasels, just three otters, four lynx, and have snared three lynx. We use brass-wire snares for the lynx and not traps. I like to be with my brother looking at the traps. It is hard work sometimes but I don't mind the work. Often I drive the dogs while my brother is forerunner. Soon we will be lifting all our traps up.

This winter I went to school only a little while. I would rather work than go to school. It is all right for my little brothers and sisters to go to school but not for a man like me.

There are still no signs of springing, though it does get mild about noon on calm days. The ice on the lakes will last for another month or more, but on the rivers it will break up sooner. To-morrow, Moses and I are going out to set our traps and bring them in. By that time father and Jeremiah will be back from the north. Then we will all go away for the spring rat-hunt. Mother and my little brothers and sisters will stay here too. They will be glad to have a holiday for they have gone to school nearly every school day this winter.

We will put all our things on our two jumpers and go over to Waskwawin Lake. That is about a three days' journey from here. We will only have to sleep three times. Amos Moose and his family are going with us. It will not take us long to pack up. We will take enough flour and tea and lard to last until the ice goes out. We will not use toboggans to go with, but jumpers. Toboggans are like flat turned-up boards, but jumpers have two runners. We use jumpers in the spring because the snow in the bush melts long before the ice on the lakes and rivers. This water runs down on to the ice of the rivers and lakes. Sometimes it is a week or more before the water has run through the cracks and the ice has left it free, and we may have to travel through four or five inches of slush. The runners on the jumpers keep things from getting wet.

When we go on the rat-hunt we will lash our canoes on to the jumpers because we will not return until open water and we will need them to come back with. We will put what we are taking with us, blankets, canvas covers, pots, pans, pails, traps, rifles, food, and clothes, into the canoes.

We are not taking any meat along except we may kill a moose or two and we like to eat the muskrats after we skin them. They are good.

When we get there we will make a camp. We will not make a house, only some pole tepees, and we will live in them. We make a tepee, or wigwam, by standing poles up in a circle about ten feet across. The tops of these poles meet and interlock. We cover them inside with pieces of canvas, birch bark, and spruce bark. This bark is easy to peel off in the spring months.

At first we will have to trap the rats through the ice; but it will soon be broken up and the ice melts in the shallow swamps where some of them build their houses. The rats like to swim in the creeks and these open up when the river breaks its banks. We set our traps along these little streams and this is how we do it. Rats like to eat bark from poplar saplings. We cut a sapling and place it along the slope bank of a stream as if it had drifted there and stuck. To the sapling we fasten the trap. Then we set it under the water at the most likely point where the rats will climb up. When he gets caught he tries to swim away and drowns. My father and Jeremiah and Moses and I should get about two hundred rats. We have to go about a dollar and a quarter apiece for them, but that we can never tell; sometimes they sell for a lot and other times they don't.

Now I must run along. Mat- thias is going to kill two muskies yesterday and he is having a feast this afternoon and a dance this evening. Moses and I are going over to his place.

And that is the story of Nehemiah. (He said as he told it to me the other day, when I went up to visit him and his mother and to buy from them a pair of moccasins to replace my old and almost worn-out pair.)
Betty in Dreamland

Fantasy by GWENDOLINE READ

Published by the Forestry Branch, Department of the Interior, Canada.

CHARACTERS

Spirits of the Trees
Betty, schoolgirl
Sugar Maple
Miss Maxwell, schoolmistress
Douglas Fir
The Stove

The Red Demon
Yellow Birch

Scene I

A schoolroom. Table, chair, stove, door, window. Betty seated at the table with writing material, head leaning on her hand, staring disconsolately out of the window.

BETTY.—It is awful to be a girl! To have to go to school! And worse than awful to have to stay in, on a glorious day like this, when there's a puff of the breeze is an invitation to run out and play. Here I am, cooped up in this dingy hole, and expected to write an essay on trees. I am sure it would do me far more good to be playing outside, studying Nature than way that having to write about trees about it, and guessing it. Who cares how long a silly tree lives, or whether its leaves are pointed or round? After all its main use in life is to burn well or build well.

(Yawning) Oh dear me! I do feel very sleepy. Well, I suppose I must make a start sometime.

(Throws up pencil, stares at exercise book, then gradually her head nods and she lays it on her arms on the table.)

Curtain

Scene II

Same schoolroom with the spirits of the trees standing artistically arranged, and the stove. Betty asleep at the table. Waking, looks wonderingly at each, rubs her eyes.

BETTY.—When on earth are you funny little creatures?

(Walking round each, inspecting each in turn)

Some of you are quite pretty. I am sure you cannot be mortals, so you must be fairies or brownies. Why, yes! I do believe you are the real brownies from the woods (clapping her hands) oh! oh! How perfectly lovely!

YELLOW BIRCH.—No, Betty, we are not brownies, but very old friends of yours. You may not recognize us, as we are at present. I am the spirit of the Yellow Birch, from which the desk is made; The White Pine, table (indicating each in turn), from whose wood the desk is made; White Pine, which provides the wood for the door, and White Spruce, the wainscoting and the paper on which you write. The stove you, of course, recognize, and dear me, I was nearly forgetting the Douglas Fir.

DOUGLAS FIR.—(Complainingly and very crossly.) Yes, indeed! and we have really come to tell Betty what we think of her! Silly trees, indeed! (turning to Betty) I wonder where you'd be if you hadn't a shelter to keep the cold and the draughts out. I have come all the way from British Columbia, through 250 miles of dignity, going through dreadful things, too. Being cut off in my youth, dragged and planed—

SUGAR MAPLE.—(Turning to Betty in apologetic way) Don't take any notice of him, Betty. Douglas Fir always did have a lot to say—though there aren't many people who can keep even him quiet.

BETTY.—And who is that?

SUGAR MAPLE.—The Red Demon! (They all shudder and look alarmed.)

BETTY.—What is the matter with all of you? Why do you look so terrified?

DOUGLAS FIR.—If hundreds and hundreds of your family had been devoured as mine have been, you would shudder. It is often mortals like you that let this demon loose.

BETTY.—Yes, yes! but tell me who he is. Is he an evil spirit? He sounds dreadful!

THE STOVE.—I am not afraid of him, he feeds me every day—though it's true I do get very red at times in my attempt to control him, and he caused this crack in my side (showing the crack).

BETTY.—(Stamping her foot) I'll hang all your silly heads together soon, if you will go on talking in riddles. WHO IS THE RED DEMON?

ALL TOGETHER.—FIRE!

BETTY.—Well, I do believe what you are making such a fuss about. Like all hot-tempered people you have to handle him with care. Very little will start him and cause a lot of trouble. Again, like one's temper, if you let it run on there is no knowing where the fire will end. So let us change the subject. Tell me about yourselves. You see, I have been kept in to write an essay on Canadian trees, so you quaint little people can help me a lot. Sugar Maple, you are so pretty that I am sure you must be in great demand.

SUGAR MAPLE.—(With much hauteur) I suppose I am the most distinguished—

DOUGLAS FIR.—(Interrupting) Nonsense! (Turning to Betty) Sugar Maple is as full of airs! You ought to go to British Columbia and we'd—YOU!

BETTY.—Oh, Douglas Fir, please stop being so arrogant, and let us hear what Sugar Maple has to say. Of course, we all know "The Maple Leaf" gives him a special right to be proud, being Canada's emblem and therefore his leaf is the emblem. Indeed, I should be proud of it myself.

SUGAR MAPLE.—We are also proud of the beautiful bird's-eye wood, which is so much sought after for special pieces of furniture—and then, of course, we also supply sugar. Unfortunately, insects are a great plague, and if only mortals...
sit on my arms here and whisper into my knotty ears and we could exchange many a secret. I know more about the world by standing still and listening to the birds than you do or could if you had twenty foolish legs to hustle you about.

"Would you believe it, last week some Cedar Birds (perhaps you call them Cherry Birds) were eating my berries while singing of the some coming to theirs from Northern Canada, and they made me their common tree! Yes sir, I was the general headquarters. The two flocks mixed together, and such a lisping and chattering!

"Bohemians were telling Cherry Birds all about the new north, and how Canada is becoming peopled far away where your legs could never carry you without help. And they said that Northern Ontario which, not so long ago, was forest, is now becoming mining and farm lands.

"One slender limb Cedars were telling Bohemians all about some terrible floods on the Mississippi River, down where Bohemians seldom go, and of floating barns and swimming people, and of water rushing down and covering the land. They were most astonished to see rivers going so wild, but all the rivers will go wild in spring when the snow melts, and dry up as dry as a bone in summer, if men with two legs and no sense go on cutting down all the trees, for trees hold back the water in spring and let it out of the ground gradually all summer.

"Oh, I heard many things they said, but what I liked best of all was what they said about me. They liked me very much; they enjoyed my berries, and made me so happy I want to sing. Listen, and I will hold my leaves in the wind and sing you a song":

SONG OF THE MOUNTAIN ASH

Oh, I am a fruiting-gay fountain,
Spray-drooping my clusters of red,
Oh, I am the Ash of the Mountain,
Who heard what the Cherry Bird said:
He said, "Oh what lovely, ripe berries!"
As jowlyly weeped:
"They're juicy and better than cherries,
I'll eat a few, saving the rest."
He told the Bohemian Warzing,
His name Canadian bird,
And when they came unexpectedly lisping,
I listened and caught every word:
They said, "Here's a tree like a fountain,
With drops of a fay-frozen dew;
Hurray for the Ash of the Mountain!"
Then admiringly they flew.

—WALLACE HAVELOCK ROBB.

Autumn Poetry

There is one song of autumn that has become a sort of birthright of every Canadian. It is "The Passing of Autumn," by Archibald Lampman. No poem is so often or so lovingly quoted at this time of year.

The wizard has woven his ancient scheme
A day and a starlit night,
And the world is a shadowy, pencilled dream
Of color, haze and light.
Like something an angel wrought, maybe,
To answer a fairy's whim,
A fold of an ancient tapestry.
A phantom, rare and dim.
Silent and smooth as the crystal stone
The river lies serene,
And the fading hills are a jewelled throne
For the Fall and the Mist, his Queen.
Slim as out of aerial seas
The elms and poplars fair
Float like the dainty spirits of trees,
In the mellow, dreamlike air.
Slivery-soft by the forest side—
Wine-red, yellow, rose—
The wizard of Autumn, faint, blue-eyed—
Swinging his censer, goes,

There are many other autumn songs by Canadians, that lovely one by Wilfrid Campbell, for instance—

Along the line of smoky hills
The crimson forest stands,
And all the day the blue-jay calls
Throughout the autumn lands.
Now by the brook the maple leans,
With all his glory spread,
And all the marshes on the hill
Have turned their green to red.
Now by great marshes wrapt in mist,
Or past some river's mouth,
Throughout the long, still autumn day
Wild birds are flying south.

The End of Summer

"When poppies in the garden bleed,
And coreopsis goes to seed,
And pansies, blossoming past their prime,
Grow small and smaller all the time;
When on the mown fields hot and dry,
Brown dust from thistle to thistle flies,
And smoke from forest fires at noon
Can make the sun appear the moon;
When apple seeds, all white before,
Begin to darken in the core,
I know that summer, scarcely here,
Is gone until another year."

—Edna St. Vincent Millay.
IT WAS a bright, warm, Saturday afternoon in early September when Zechariah Loonfoot, my young Indian friend, and I strode through the bush along the path that led from the Mission buildings to a bit of sandy beach about a half-mile up the lake shore. Had we followed the trail, we should have been a half-hour scrambling over great rocks and skirting deep bays; the path, though in a few places a little muskeggy, was much shorter and easier. In minutes we pushed past the fringe of willows on the edge of the forest-growth and came out on the beach. Fifty yards on each side of us the wind swept the break-end, and the shore continued as steep, rocky ledges, sometimes shelving and sometimes dropping sharply into the lake. From the water to the trees the yellow sand could have been paced in a score of long steps.

A breeze blowing off the lake soon dispersed the swarm of mosquitoes that had gathered there that followed us out of the bush.

As usual, when Zechariah was around the Mission and we were able to slip away without the smaller children following us, we hurried off with our clothes as a race for first into the water; and as usual, Zechariah, who wore only a shirt, a pair of pants, and moccasins, and what were once socks, was splashing and blowing before I rushed into the cold, crystal-clear lake.

Even in the hot summer days we had been glad to get out of the water; it was so cold; and so it was that soon we were sprawled full-length on the sand, Zechariah's dark-brown skin glistening in the dazzling rays of the low September sun.

Ours was a strange companionship. I was the teacher of the school on the Reserve which was in fact the Mission, and Zechariah was a young Cree Indian lad about sixteen years old. He could speak and understand a little English, and I could speak and understand a little of his native language. Sometimes I would try to tell him about the great outside world which he had never seen; about the roads and trains, and large boats, and high build- ings, and bridges, and other man-made wonders; while he, in his turn, would try to tell me about his life and the things he had done.

That Saturday afternoon, in early September, I was the first to break our silence.

"You are going away soon, Zechariah?" I asked him in his language.

"Yes," he answered in English, clipping the word off short, as was his habit.

We lapsed back into silence. In a few minutes I asked again:

"Where are you going to trap this winter?"

"Kesatinew Sani?" he replied this time in Cree.

"Old Man River, eh?" I returned, to make sure I understood him.

"Uh-huh," he grunted, as he gazed out over the lake with his sombre, black eyes.

"When are you leaving?" I questioned, after another short silence.

"Maybe next week;" this time he spoke in English.

Silence dropped between us once more.

"How do you go from here?"

Zechariah made no move to answer my question, but I understood him and waited; I knew that when he became impatient he often shut up into impenetrables. I lay still on my stomach, and, chin cupped in my hands, idly watched the tiny waves breaking, one following the other, on the rippling sand.

Suddenly he stirred himself, reached for a bit of stick that lay near by, and began to smooth out the sand that was between him and me. I sensed a story.

"It's like this," he commenced; and here I set down for you just what he told me, partly in English and partly in Cree:

"That is Forgetful Lake," he made a little circle in the smoothed area of sand, "and this is where the Mission is;" he stuck a bit of twig on the shore of his round of Forgetful Lake, "the directions will be the same as Nature."

"You know how every fall most of my people leave the river and move away to trap through the long winter. Summer is over and some of them have already gone. There are not many fur-bearing animals near the Reserve; they have been killed off or frightened away, so we have to scatter over the country in order to get enough to make a living. Several families will together and build shacks on the bank of a lake or river. They may travel a week, or even two weeks, from the Reserve before they make their camps. In these camps or camps they will live all winter, and from them the men will set out their trappings.

"I think my father has decided to leave maybe next week. There are about twenty of us going up to Old Man River. We shall make a camp together. There are my..."
father, and mother and my two sisters, and my young brother and myself; there are my maiden brother and his wife, and family of four; there are my father's brother and his wife; there are my mother's sister's husband and family, of six children; that's twenty-eight of us," he counted them off on his fingers.

"It will take four eighteen-foot canoes to carry us and our things, for we shall take all the things from our homes except the hand-made beds and tables and chairs, and the stoves. We will not need the furniture in our camp, and we will make firesides instead of carrying stoves. We shall have to take with us all our bed-clothes, our pots and pans and pails, our axes and guns and traps, our clothes and food. We shall last until Christmas or longer, lard and tea and sugar and jam and baking-powder, cartridges for the guns, fish-nets, and odds and ends. We shall have to put in the canoes too, for our dogs and their harness and the toboggans; we shall need them for winter travel.

"When we leave here we shall go up the Rat River," said he marked on his sand map with his stick the course of the Rat River, which empties into Footprint Lake on the west. "Although this river flows from the northeast, and where we are going is on Old Man River is northeast of here—this roundabout way is the best canoe route. We have about 350 miles to go and if we are not held up by heavy fall winds or rains we should make it in a little over two weeks. We go up the Rat River to its head. There are twenty-three portages around rapids, but they are mostly short ones.

"Along the Rat River there are several lakes. Here is Swan Lake," and he drew on the sand a small circle a short distance up the river. "The next lake is Pemachikamaw, and it was put on the sand map.

"What does Pemachikamaw mean?" I interrupted.

"It is Cree for Grass Lake," Zechariah answered. "It is a long, narrow lake lying at right-angles to the river. We cross over it about the centre. Between Cross Lake and Swan Lake the country is very rough and there are many falls and rapids while we shall have to go around. They make new roads. When we come to a portage we all have to get out and everything must be carried over it. The women and children all help. When the canoe is across we have to put the canoe in the water again and reload it.

"Portaging is hard work. We use pack-straps. They are long leather straps fastened to a wide head-piece of leather. The straps are tied around the ends of a box or something, leaving a loop with

"When everything is across we have to put the canoe in the water again and reload it."

the head-piece in the centre of it. Then this head-piece goes across the forehead and the box rests on the back. The rear end of the load is placed on top. We usually carry from two to three hundred pounds, but I have seen men trot over a portage with 400 pounds. The women and children carry the awkward things across the portages, such as paddles, oars, loose blankets and small articles. If it is a long portage, oars are fastened to the thwarts, the distance and one man carries it over, but on a short portage two men take it, one at each end, and jog over with it. An eighteen-foot canoe weighs about 170 pounds, but they are very awkward and bump into the trees.

"At night we shall make camp wherever we happen to be. If it rains, we shall make shelters out of canvas covers. Our beds will be our blankets laid on a mattress of spruce-boughs on the ground. Our camp fire will give us heat and light. Each night we camp we shall have to set a net to get fish for the dogs and for ourselves. We shall lift it each morning and take it with us.

"Other lakes on the Rat River are called 'Footprint Lake,' Notigi Lake and Karsakuwikamak Lake," and he marked them down on his sand map. "Wuchusk means 'rat' and the lake is so named because its shores are low and muskrats build their houses there. Notigi means 'old-wife.' Long, long ago, when my father's father was a little boy, an old woman stood on this camp on the shores of this lake. She was never found, because a spirit took her away to keep his fire burning. Ever since the lake has been called Notigi Lake. 'Nenawitwik' means 'narrow.' This lake is long and narrow, and is but a widening of the river; hence the name.

"We go right along the Rat River until we come a little wind creek among some sand and stone hills. That is a height of land. We must then cross over a three-mile portage, and then go down, down, and go down it. That brings us to a large lake called Ithinwey, or Indian Lake, which is a part of the Churchill River." Indian Lake was named after the Indians, in a north and south direction. "We go down this lake, keeping close to the shore. It is too big to go out in with our small canoes. We shall not make camp near the edge of this lake. It is joined to Sandy Lake by a short river which we go down." And Zechariah drew the lake and river, changing the course to run by east. On this river is Missi, or Big, Falls. It is only twenty feet high, but it is many hundred feet wide. It makes an awful noise. We go across Sandy Lake, and then to the Churchill River to where Old Man River empties into it. There are many portages along the Churchill River. Then we follow Old Man River and travel about a day and a half to where we are going to make our camp. That will be near a wide, shallow rapid where the fishing is good."
Zechariah completed his map by adding the Churchill River, running east and the Old Man River entering it from the north. Where the camp was to be he stuck another small twig.

"First, the men will build our winter homes. These will be square, log shacks, two of them. They will be about ten feet on a side. The roofs will be low and flat, made of poles covered with moss. There will be no windows, but the light will come in through a hole in the roof. These holes will be just over the heads of the fireplaces, which we shall make, one in each shack, of mud and stones and stones. The walls will be chinked with moss. The floors will be the ground covered with spruce boughs, and will be our beds, tables and chairs. The fireplaces will give us light at night.

"It will take them two or three days to build these houses. The women will set the nets just below the rapids and catch fish. We have many dogs and that will mean a great many fish during the winter months. We catch them in the fall and hang them up in racks. The days are cold enough to freeze them until they freeze solid. To hang them we use sticks about thirty inches long and about one inch thick. Ten fish are threaded through the tails on to each stick. These fish sticks are hung up in a rack out of reach of the dogs. Each dog needs a good-sized fish a day, so we shall have to kill about 5,000 fish. They are very plentiful there, and that will mean only a few days' work.

"Usually, as far north as that, about the middle of October the smaller lakes and rivers have frozen over and we can travel on them. But a lot of snow comes before the waters freeze solid. From our winter camp we shall set out our traplines. There will be four of them running out in different directions. We will average about 150 traps apiece, as well as snares and deadfalls. We don't know how long they will be yet; that depends on what the fur signs are like. Our traplines generally take a week or ten days to go out to the end of them. They keep us busy.

"There are many falls and rapids which we shall have to go around."

"We shall live in our shacks all winter. While the men hunt and trap, the women will tan the moose, dress the hides, make coats, pants, mitts and moccasins of them. We do not tan the other animals dry, but use them as stretchers. That will be part of the women's work, too. The animals we catch in our traps—foxes, lynx, mink, martens, weasels, wolves, otters, die, and we skin and freeze stiff. We have to bring them to camp and thaw them out before the women can skin them and dry the pelts.

"Just before Christmas, my father and I plan to come back by dog-sleigh. We shall bring two teams and carry what fur we have killed. The winter route is across country. Zechariah drew almost a straight line from the camp to Footprint Lake—and we can make it in about six days coming out. We shall stay for Christmas and take back with us supplies for the camp. The trip loaded, will take about nine days, as they are so short then and we cannot travel by night.

"We expect to come out for Easter time. Then my big brother and my uncle will come then. They will bring down fur and take back supplies. The days are getting shorter and the trip will be shorter and easier.

"In the spring, when many of the animals are past prime, the muskrat season begins. Old Man River is so far north that we can trap rats up there. Then we shall pack up our whole outfit and come back by the canoe route. We shall be here again around the end of June and shall fly all summer in our houses. Treaty time is about the middle of July, when we get our Five Dollars each and the twine for nets and the cartridges for guns.

"Before we leave it, we shall have danced and sung the summer away and it will be time to get ready to go north for winter trapping again."

His story came to an abrupt end. For several minutes we lay there; he, slowly erasing his sand map with deliberate strokes of his stick; I, watching his brown face with its fine features—the flashing black eyes, the thin nose, square chin, small, generally silent mouth—an Indian, I thought, a nomad of the North.

As yet I made no comments on what he had said; I had learned that silence was to him the best appreciation.

Suddenly I became aware that a cool shadow was across me; the sun was sinking behind the trees.

"Time to go, Zechariah," I stirred.

He looked toward the sun.

"Yes," he said in his precise way.

We hopped up, brushed off the saplings and were quickly dressed. A few minutes later we were padding our way along the bush trail in the direction of the Mission.

The Fire-Fly Lantern

By WALLACE HAVELOCK ROBB, OF ABBEY DAWN

I know a gnome named Gramkin;
He lives in a gnarled oak.
He carries a lighted pumpkin,
And he knows all fairy folk.

I met him in the twilight,
Inviting fire-flies
To come and make his lantern bright
With twinkles in its eyes.

"Ho, ho!" laughed grim old Gramkin,
"No candle light for me!
Mine is a magic lantern —
A pumpkin that can see!"

"Come fire-flies," Gram chuckled,
"It's dark! Don't be so slow!"
The pumpkin eyes then twinkled —
The lantern was aglow!
"The John Harpers, you mean? It is his way. We Indians have always lived in bands, and even when the white man's government made treaty with us we were given reserves to make our homes on. We do not mix our tribes much and thus there is a lot of close intermarriage. Some of the family names have been swallowed up. My people are fond of naming children after relatives and in this spirit will allow a child who has been named after some one who has done something big. Many years ago there was a man the white traders named John. This man travelled 260 miles across country in three days to carry news of a strange sickness and seek help for his people. So you see the standing of one of the family names and the fortune attached to 'John' caused five John Harpers here."

I smiled inwardly at his naive explanation.

"You people like names from the Bible, don't they, Isaac?" I asked, hoping to draw him out again.

"Yes, netotam, they are good names. My English name is Isaac. I like it. I like Indian names too. Kahasaskakannes means 'little quill.' I have four brothers and a sister, Laban, Joshua, David, Joseph, Solomon and Rebecca. They are good names also."

When Isaac named his brothers and sister so, I recalled an incident of my first year's teaching among Indians. It was preparatory to the settlement. An old father had chosen, all in good faith, Beelzebub, as the name for his new son! It was only after much and long arguing that the father finally gave up the idea; he went home deciding to choose another name.

The day of the christening arrived, and little Macdonald was named Nochachadnezzar, for nothing would induce the father to change again!

"Have your brothers and sisters Indian names, too?" I asked Isaac after some minutes silence.

"We all have Indian names," he answered shortly.

I saw I had asked a tactless question. The old man was hurt. There was, I saw then, Indian pride in the older of the twins. Even if the white man could plant new names of his choosing on them, they could have their own names also.

"And these names, Isaac," I continued, "in an effort to keep a warm atmosphere between us, how are they given?"

"Sometimes they are the name of an illustrious ancestor. Sometimes they are given because of a place where one is born, such as Kecheesun, 'big rock.' Sometimes they are given because of something that happens the time of birth, such as Tawelwaim, 'thousand-moon.' These names sometimes change. You know David Spence? His name used to be Sokenep, 'loud-water.' But later someone was called by this name. Now we call him Maskwanapao, 'the bear-man.' It is sleep time."

Isaac broke off his narrative with characteristic Indian abruptness. Fully aroused, he slipped between the folds of his rabbit-skin robe and cuddled up like a curled dog.

More leisurely, I pulled off my mocassin, unbuttoned them up in my coat for a pillow, crawled into my elderdown sleeping-bag, loosened my belt and braces, and stretched out with a contented sigh.

The stars overhead twinkled brightly. The Great Dipper was standing on its handle, the Three Moons Hunters were dropping behind the treeline. The Night that was near us was at peace. Isaac's heavy breathing indicated sleep. My last recollection was a dull pop of a cooling fire-brand. I fell asleep.
