The Adventures of Mostly Neck

By WALLACE HAVELOCK ROBB, OF ABBEY DAWN

This is a thrilling story, with photos, especially for the readers of "The Canadian Red Cross Junior."

THIS is not a long story, but it is a happy one. "Mostly Neck" is the odd name we gave to a bird in our Sanctuary. And how do you suppose he got that name? Well, it is one of the nicest stories that could ever happen.

I'll tell you about it.

"Mostly Neck" was a sick, sad, sorry, and starving bird. He was a prisoner held by a cruel, hateful wife who fastened around his leg. And how he managed to break away from the mean and hard-hearted person who held him captive no one can say.

All I know is this: He had been found in a garden in Kingston, trying to catch a bug or two for breakfast, or a toad—oh, the poor toad! I suppose he could swallow a toad, but toads are much like frogs, and these birds live on frogs and such like. Anyhow, there he was, standing among the stalky plants and trying to look as much like one as possible, for he is a Bittern.

Around this poor, unfortunate Bittern had gathered a crowd. Everyone was afraid to go near him, for fear of his sharp beak. Very wise people I should say, for one jab of that swordlike beak would stab like a knife!

So the people craned their necks to see the bird at him, and he craned back at them and, I suppose, that is how it comes that these long legged and long necked birds are commonly called cranes. He has a very new thought for a silly and double reason. You see, he is a Bittern, and he lives among the reeds and rushes. Now, here's a strange thing: Mother Nature has made his tall stout body so he could not be so conspicuous, so easily seen, when in his home surroundings. But after she looked him over she saw how easily she could see him among the reeds. Mother Nature said something like this: "Tut, tut! This will never do! You're still so fat and bulky that any stranger could pick you out and see you plainly. I shall have to paint you in long, straight lines. I'll make your feathers grow so that when you hear people or enemies coming, just crane and stretch as tall and thin as possible."

All the children wanted to see him, so they were permitted to view him at close range.

"Oh, look!" said one, "What a shame! Look, Mister, the wire is cutting his legs." So we gently removed it. Then another said, "He's a crane, all right; I have seen ones like him in the marshes. His legs are the biggest part of him!"

"Go on!" countered another chap about twelve years old, still holding his little sister on his back so she could see better, "Legs nothing! He's mostly neck!" And when he swallows a frog it has a long way to drop it.

Everyone laughed with glee and glee, for they knew the bird was in kind hands. So I said, "We'll let the Bittern go free in the Sanctuary at Abbey Dawn, but we'll call him 'Mostly Neck' until he is able to fly away."

Poor Mostly Neck was so empty that he nearly died, for the mean people who tied him a captive either could not feed him or had not the sort of food he liked. But we soon fed him, and before night he was feeling better. Another night we tried to put some life into him that he tried to fly and actually did fly from the kitchen table to the sink. So we said, "Let Mostly Neck go. He's well enough to find his own food."

And would you believe it? he was in such hurry to fly away. So I said, after I had sent my lad, Joe, for my camera, "I'd like to get your picture for the children of the Red Cross Junior, and tell them of your adventures. Will you stand still, Mostly Neck?"

Mostly Neck stiffened up, stretched his neck to its limit, craned, and tried to look his streaky best. Then, when he heard the camera click, he quietly retreated to the safety of the sanctuary reeds. He flew up a few hours later, but descended again in another marsh in the sanctuary.
OLD ISAAC had often agreed to take me muskrat hunting with him, and as the weather promised to be particularly fine, I persuaded him to set out Friday afternoon after school. We loaded a small canoe, tied it on a sled, a snowshoe runner, and stowed our outfit in it—a .22 rifle, a shotgun, traps, hand-axes, paddles, some rope, bed-rolls, and the grub-bag.

It was three mile above across the great ice cake that persisted in the lake, for it was thick and strong, and the rays of the May sun had made little impression except along the edges where it was shallow. Even there it was only melted ten or fifteen feet from the shore because the bottom shelved away rather steeply. The smooth runners of our sled sped easily along, and when we reached the other side of the lake where a small creek emptied, we untied the canoe, slid it into the water, loaded the sled on it and paddled off up stream.

In Manitoba's north the snow on the land melts long before the lake does, and the resulting water floods streams which pour it down to rivers and lakes. It was up one of these flooded streams that we paddled, or with the first spring thaw the muskrats, or "wachusks," come out of their winter lodges and search the banks of running water for fresh roots and the new bark of trees along the shores.

We spent the first day nosing up stream, making rat sets at likely spots. This was done by cutting aspen saplings, sticking them in the mud along the water's edge, and setting the trap under water close by. When the rat, swimming along in the stream, felt the twig, he would come inshore to feed on the bark and he would step into the trap.

Friday night found us five miles up the creek, camped along the shore. A blazing fire lighted a mat of spruce boughs which kept our feet off the cold ground, and which would have been our bed. Our stomachs were satisfied with boiled duck, for during the day we had surprised a flock of mallards and old Isaac had

"My name, netotam, is also Kekanaskaskannes," and old Isaac sipped more tea.

"But you have two names. How is that?" I asked.

My old Indian companion knocked the finished embers from his pipe, rolled it in green much moss of a bear's bladder, and picking up a blazing twig from the fire relit it. I watched his methodic movements with little patience for a second, but then the meaning of it, not a story, some interesting comments. An Indian isn't to be hurried when you want him to talk.

"Old is this way, netotam," and he was comfortably squatting cross-legged on his rabbit-skin bed-roll, "Long years before the white man came we all had Indian names. There was Kechechekesik, 'big star,' and Mesenepe, 'big water,' and Papase, 'the woodpecker,' and many others. But when the white man came he couldn't remember our name in our strange tongue, so he gave us names in his own language. My father was Metonoconehik, 'big wood,' and he was named James McPherson by the white traders. My father's brother was Wastasekot, 'bright nose,' and he was named Samuel Ross. And so were many of our men. But while the white man called us new names in his strange language, we were always named by our own people also.

"Sometimes the white man when he gave us new names just translated our Indian names; Oskan became Edward 'Bone,' Kechekeesik became John and so on. And again our old names were sometimes used. You know John Napatapew. That means 'a row of birds.'"

Isaac lapsed into silence and I feared my entreaties was to stop. Perhaps I could draw him out.

"But if you were all given new names," I asked, "how is it that there are five men on this reserve with the same name?"

This is Isaac, my old Indian friend who told me so much about the names of his people that starlit May night as we sat around the fire on spruce boughs before a camp-fire.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

As you will remember from previous correspondence, Miss Irene Bell is being transferred to the Junior Room at Christian Island.

For the Nelson House Indian Day School we wish to nominate Mr. Swart Monias. Mr. Monias is a member of the Island Lake Band, a graduate of our Norway House Residential School where, on passing the Entrance examinations, he secured the highest marks of any pupil in the jurisdiction of that Public School Inspector. He has since spent several years in the Brandon School acquiring both Junior and Senior Matriculation with First Class Honours, and has recently completed his Normal training in the Brandon Normal School with great distinction. I have letters from the Principal and the Director of Physical Education at the Brandon Normal speaking in the highest terms of Mr. Monias, both as a student and a teacher.

It has been my privilege to keep pretty closely in touch with him for six years. I know his ability as a teacher from having seen him in action as a supply teacher in the Brandon School on the occasion of one of my visits.

He will marry an Indian girl, also a graduate of the Brandon School. The United Church of Canada has a small house at Nelson House which will be placed at his disposal, and we are prepared to pay travelling expenses for himself and his wife to the School even though this is a pretty heavy item. There is no furniture in the residence which we are offering him, and I am wondering if the Department could make a small grant towards furnishing it.

I hope that you will see your way clear to approve of this nomination and that the salary will be set at not less than $25 a teaching month, which is the present rate. I would appreciate an early reply in view of the fact that Mr.
Monias desires to visit his people before going into Nelson House. He has not been home for several years.

We realize that this is an experiment, but our missionary at Nelson House, Rev. A. C. Houston, who is a young man only three or four years out of College, has promised to give Mr. Monias every assistance, and there is probably no place in Canada where we could try him out to better advantage.

Yours very sincerely,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 123-11-1 of the 26th July, advising of the approval of the appointment by the Home Mission Board of the United Church of Canada of Mr Ewart Monias as teacher of the United Church Indian School at Nelson House.

As Nelson House is attached to The Pas Agency, I have taken the liberty of forwarding a copy of the Department's letter to Mr G. Lovell, Indian Agent at The Pas, and I am writing to him and asking him to advise the Department as to the best way of getting some house furnishings out to Nelson House, as I am not acquainted with the methods of transportation to that particular point. On making enquiries here, however, I am advised that it would not be possible to get furniture to Nelson House until the winter time when it could be shipped from the N.B.Railway to freight it out to Nelson House. The shipment would, I imagine, go by Hudson's Bay Railway to Wabowen, and be freighted out from there to Nelson House.

With reference to the furnishings for the teacher's house, I have made a list of what I consider will be necessary, not including such things as bed linen, towels, table-cloth, etc., such alike. The cost of the items listed amounts to approximately $175.00 at Winnipeg; the list having been made up from Eaton's catalogue.

I am requesting Mr Agent Lovell to advise the Department as to getting the furniture to Nelson House, immediately on receipt of my letter.

As Mr Monias will travel to Nelson House via The Pas, I expect, it would be well for him to report at the office of the Indian Agency there, where he would no doubt obtain information that would simplify his journey somewhat, between there and his destination.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lasenby,
Indian Agent.

When one gets away from The Pas, schools are few and far between. We visited five reserves and found only three schools functioning - two at Nelson House and one at Split Lake. I did not have time to visit the Nelson House School at Catholic Point, but at the other school there were 49 pupils in a room 21 x 23 and in which there was a scarcity of suitable desks. Mr. Lovell thought it advisable to have a dozen of the younger ones stay at home. This, I think, was a wise decision rather than have so much overcrowding. Had many of these pupils not lived so far from school, arrangements might have been made for them to attend in two groups half a day each. This tends to keep up their interest in the school. I understand that there will be a certain number going from here to South Indian Lake to take part in fishing operations next fall and winter. Dear Sir:

When Major McKay, Commissioner for B.C., was giving evidence last year before the joint committee studying Indian Affairs, he mentioned that several day schools there (I think it was 8) were operating on a 2 day basis—one shift in the morning, another in the afternoon. This was because of lack of accommodation—a condition which also prevails here. I wonder then, if the above plan could be put into operation here this following year?

The reasons for this suggestion follow. First, there are a large number of children on the reserve. Even though there are two day schools, one U.C., the other R.C., and more than 30 were away at Residential School, many children are not enrolled. In the year...
In 1945-46, there were 57 enrolled at the R.C. School, until the agent sent almost half of them home. In 1946-47, enrollment was kept down to 40, and an average attendance of 27 was made possible only by the use of tables, biscuit boxes etc., to supplement the desks in the school. Of the 23 at the R.C. day school this past year 14 were Protestant children attending there in part because of proximity, in part because of the shortage of accommodation at the R.C. School.

Furthermore, the agent apparently refuses the family allowance regulations, until such time as there is accommodation for all children. Warning have been given the parents, and I have recommended that children be cut off because of irregular attendance without reasonable excuse. Nothing was done about it by our agent. It is getting to the point where this is causing hard feeling in the community. Some children do not see why they should attend regularly when...
others do not, and continue to get F.A. This has been brought to my attention on more than one occasion. Apart from this, there is the difficulty which the teacher encounters in trying to make classes move along shortly when 50% of them come perhaps 3 days in 5.

I will list a few attendances to illustrate my point.

1. Nelson Linklater (15) absent October 5 days
   November 5
   December 3
   January 5
   February 6
   March 8
   April 10

2. Sandy Spence (15) - attended school until late October. Went off trapping until Christmas. Worked several days at Mr. Smith's until late April, when once there he went trapping. Besides earning money he continued to get F.A.

3. Babian Moor - an R.C child who enrolled Oct. 15 at v/c school. She attended quite regularly until Christmas - one day since.

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Federal Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir:

I was in your office some ten days ago enquiring about plans for the coming school year at Nelson House. I pointed out the need for more accommodation than the new school provides and suggested that the old school should be operated along with the new. You asked me to set forth the particulars in writing.

The Nelson House band has more than five hundred members. This does not count those who in recent years have taken up their residence at South Indian Lake. Of the above number at least two hundred and twenty seven are children of sixteen or under. One hundred and nineteen are from six to sixteen, one hundred and eight are under six. Both Roman Catholics and Protestants are represented. Taking a Protestant child to be "one born of Protestant parents" there are ninety five of school age and eighty one under it. There are twenty four Roman Catholic children of school age and twenty seven under it. In these figures I have included the children of four non-treaty families, six of school age and six under.

In the past the community has been served by two day schools, one Protestant the other Roman Catholic, each with
accommodation for about twenty-five pupils. But as might be expected denominational lines have not been clear-cut. Without exception the children have attended the closer school. For instance during the school year 1946-47 fourteen out of the twenty-five attending the Roman Catholic School came from nearby Protestant homes. At the same time only one Roman Catholic child was attending the Protestant school. This sort of thing will continue so long as there are "separate" schools.

The parents of this reserve are almost unanimous in their desire for the residential school system. They expressed themselves that way in a letter to the Commons' committee on Indian Affairs and again at a meeting before the Indian Agent last summer. But they have objected in the past about having to send their children so far away. Right now the priest, Father Thiboutot, is active in signing up families, Roman Catholic and Protestant, who want to have their children in a boarding school on or near the reserve. With or without foundation, Father Thiboutot still hopes such a school will be built under the auspices of his church. We are inclined to accept the apparent decision of the department that this reserve is to be served by day schools.

From what I have said it will be apparent that both the new and the old schools should be operated during the next
year and that plans should be made for early expansion of school facilities. The information I have given can be presented to and verified by Mr. Law when he comes next month. Rev. C. H. Best should be notified as soon as it is known that another teacher will be required. His address is 441 Somerset Bldg., Winnipeg.

I am sorry to burden you with this rather lengthy summary but I think it does raise all the major factors to be considered.

A very rough sketch of our community is enclosed.

Yours truly,

Murray S. Thompson.

Extract from Regional Supervisor Davis' report dated January 4th on the Nelson House U.C. Indian Day School.

The teacher of this school is Miss Ruth Jardine. She appears to me to be more or less untidy and a little sloppy in her methods. However, the school was not in operation when I visited, as it was early in the morning.

Mr. Grafton inspected the school after my visit and I am forwarding his report. There are 43 children on the roll and 25 of school age living around the village who are not attending school owing to a lack of accommodation.

I would recommend that the old school building be repaired and another teacher hired to look after these pupils. I would estimate the cost of repairs at about $250.00. Some desks would be required, but for the time being tables could be erected by Mr. Arnfinson, who is a fairly good carpenter.

Ottawa, December 14th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, informing the Department that Miss D. Hall, teacher of the Methodist Indian Day School at Nelson House, has given up her duties. While you have not stated the date she left Nelson House, it is presumed that it was at the end of September, as it is noted that she did not teach during October.

The appointment of her sister, Miss J. E. Hall, as teacher to succeed her is approved. We will allow her salary at the same rate as was paid Miss D. Hall. I may say that we cannot pay salary for any period in the school year exceeding 10 months, as the payment of all salaries is based on that length of service. I may say further as the questions for salary for this school are forwarded to the treasurer of the Methodist Church they will, no doubt, arrange for the payment to Miss D. Hall and her sister for the yearly teaching period. When we receive the quarterly returns from Miss J. E. Hall covering the period she teaches to June 30th, next, consideration will be given to the amount of salary the Department will forward to the Church authorities.

Unless the Indian children are perfectly willing to attend on Saturdays, the Department would not be favourably disposed to have the school open on that day. This matter, however, will be left with the teacher and yourself to arrange.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

I am, Sir,

Ottawa, July 22nd, 1926.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 13th instant, relative to the request of Miss J. E. Hall, teacher of the Nelson House Methodist Indian Day School, for permission to keep the school open during July and August, as the Indians are home from the hunting ground and the attendance will be good.

In reply I beg to say that if Miss Hall keeps this school open during the present month, we will allow her payment for same. As you were informed in official letter of December 14th, last, we cannot pay salary for any period in the school year exceeding ten months. Miss Dorothy Hall was allowed payment for the month of September, 1925, and Miss J. E. Hall has been paid for the period from November 1st to June 30th, making a total of nine months for which salary has been paid during the school year closed June 30th. We will allow Miss J. E. Hall payment for the current month, in order to complete the ten months in the school year. We prefer that this school remain closed during the regular summer holiday period, and the teacher should respectfully close this school and arrange to reopen it on the first of September, next. Please arrange with her to forward a return showing the period taught by her during the current month, when a cheque in payment of one month's salary will be sent.

I may state that all cheques for salary for this school are forwarded to the Treasurer of the Methodist Church, Toronto. The Treasurer has, no doubt, paid the Misses Hall their full yearly salaries.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, December 14, 1926,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, informing the Department that Mrs. Hutty, wife of the missionary, has taken over the teaching at the Nelson House Methodist Indian Day School, succeeding Miss J. E. Hall, who gave up duties at the end of July, last.

We were informed by the Rev. T. Ferrier, who recently visited the Department, of the arrangements made for Mrs. Hutty to carry on the work at the school until such time as the services of a suitable teacher can be obtained. The Department has approved of this arrangement, and Mrs. Hutty will be allowed salary during the period she teaches at the rate of $95 per teaching month. We note that she reopened the school on or about October 1st, last.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to reply to your letter No.128-11-3 of the 25th ultimo, regarding the Nelson House U.C. Indian Day School.

Wish to say Mr. Hanna must have been absent from the school all of January, as he arrived in The Pas January 6th, 1932 so must have left South Indian Lake, where he was teaching school at the end of December 1931.

He returned to The Pas January 28th, 1932 and left the next day for Wabowden, and would get back to the Nelson House Reserve around the beginning of February.

After Mr. Hanna left the children going to Residential school, here, he went to Winnipeg, and as far as I know no authority was granted for this.

Ottawa, May 9th, 1932.

Reverend Sir,

When the March quarter return of the Nelson House U.C. Indian Day School was received, it was noted that the school was only open for part of the quarter and inquiries were made from the Indian Agent regarding the reason for this. It is found that the teacher, Mr. D.W. Hanna, left the reserve about the end of December and reached The Pas on January 6th, bringing with him some children to be placed in a residential school. He then proceeded to Winnipeg and did not return to The Pas until January 28th and would, therefore, be unable to reach Nelson House until about the first of February. You will note, therefore, that he was absent from the school for the full month of January.

The Department, however, was not aware of this when the March quarter return was received and cheque #7897 for the full quarter's salary was issued and sent to you on April 13th.

Under these circumstances, it is considered that the Department should not have allowed salary for the month of January and a deduction will be made when paying the June quarter salary.

Your obedient servant,

Board of Home Missions,
United Church of Canada,
299 Queen St. West,
Toronto 2, Ont.

Sir,

Your letter #116 duly received and reply would say that I have carefully examined the present school building and would beg to make the following report and suggestions.

The building is 16x20ft and 10ft post, inside measurements. It is simply a log building, with poles and bark for a roof. The walls are uncovered, having received a coat of mud inside and out. The floor is of single thin, unplanned lumber. The windows, four in number are eight lights, 10x12, two of these are in good repair, only requiring a few panes of glass, the remaining two were destroyed, and have been re-placed with storm windows of a smaller size. The logs in this building are all sound and good and of splendid size.

I am of the opinion that if this building was taken down and re-built, properly finished is all that is required; and would meet the requirements for some years to come. I would suggest the following improvements.

Replace the roof with proper lumber, then give it a covering of Rubber Roof Felting. Sheath the whole inside, viz., four walls and the ceiling, and lay a double floor of matched lumber. Give the windows proper attention, would suggest twelve lights size 10x12. A good mud chimney could be easily built, and would serve as a protection against fires. The outer walls if properly mudded is all that is necessary.

If the above suggestions are carried out the following materials are necessary.

Sir,

I beg leave to forward a School Report for the month of January, from the Revd H.T. Wright, Missionary and School Teacher at Nelson House.

By his report you will be able to judge of the conditions of the school building at Nelson House, and how nearly impossible it is for a school teacher to keep school open, owing to the reasons mentioned in his report.

I beg to submit for the Department's careful consideration why Indian Boarding schools of not too expensive nature should be erected at Nelson House and Split Lake for the benefit of the Indian children at these places.

At Nelson House there are over 200 children of school age, as I took the trouble to have them mustered out and counted. These are pretty evenly divided between the Methodists and Roman Catholics. At Split Lake there are quite a number of children also, somewhere in the neighbourhood of 75 or 100, these all belong to the Anglican Church, and as such are not taken in the Methodist Indian Boarding Schools either at Norway House or elsewhere, or probably more likely the different Denominations don't wish to mix up the children, but wish to keep them separate, and educate them according to the faith to which they belong.

The only solution that I can see to the education of these children lays in some sort of a Boarding school that the children could be housed and kept at school while their parents were away at their hunting grounds.

Such a building could be constructed of logs and shingled with steel shingles so as to make it fire-proof, much the same as the H.B. Company's buildings are covered with. The building should be two storey's in height. On

(over)
On the lower floor a dining room of say, 18 x 18, a living room for the girls on one end 18 x 18, and one on the other end of the building for the boys, 18 x 18 with a kitchen attached to the building say, 20 x 30; this would make the building a length of 56 ft x 20 ft wide. Upstairs, sleeping quarters for the boys and girls and teaching staff would be laid out accordingly. A class room 18 x 30 and a store-house 18 x 20 could be erected apart from the main building. The expense of these buildings put up with the material of the country ought not to cost a great deal.

The only material required to be freighted in would be doors, window sash, nails, steel shingles, building paper, tar paper, also desks for the school, furniture for the boarding department, and stoves and kitchen utensils.

A building like this I should think might be built at a cost of two or three thousand dollars or very little more. Lumber for the building would be sawn on the ground.

The H.B. Company have had no difficulty in putting up buildings almost as big as this for stores and dwelling houses, and they seem to have been built at a reasonable figure. A boarding school of the size and cost that is going to be erected at Norway House, is not what is wanted at Nelson House or Split Lake. It is such a building as the H.B. Company is in the habit of putting up at their Trading Posts, that is required for the present, so that these Indians' children will have a chance to get their children educated.

In regard to labour two good carpenters from Selkirk or possibly they might even be got at Norway House, would be sufficient with the help of the Indian labour down there. The food for the school would depend largely on moose and deer meat and fish of all descriptions, with the necessary amount of flour, bacon lard, tea, sugar, condensed milk and Butter.

In submitting this report on the probable cost of such schools required at Split Lake and Nelson House, I beg to state that I only wish to show the Department what these Indians and Missionaries want for the present.

In future years when the country (over)
country is opened up more by railroads, then more suitable buildings could be erected at a reasonable cost. But this is far distant yet, so I have outlined a building that could be put up for the present, which would be of more use to the Indians' children, and give more satisfaction to the Missionaries, as then they would be able to educate the children properly at their own homes.

Education among these Indians living so far out from civilization is necessarily slow, and will never be accomplished by day schools, as the children are never there to attend school but are taken away by their parents wherever they can find food for them and for which one can hardly blame them.

By adopting this kind of school a beginning would be made and as their children grow up and marry and in the course of time have children, they would naturally see the benefits of education and be glad to learn so as to be able to earn their living in a different manner from what they are now doing, for the country in the future I fear will be very much depleted of fur which at present is their chief mode of gaining a livelihood, and thus by educating them now, gives them a better chance to cope for the welfare of their families in the future.

Respectfully submitting this for your careful consideration.

I have the Honour to be Sir,

REPORT OF OFFICIAL VISIT TO SPLIT LAKE AND NELSON HOUSE RESERVES.

Sir,

Chief Peter Moose asked on behalf of his band, supported by the Revd. Mr. Nutty their Missionary, that the Department build a new day school on their reserve, as the old school was inadequate for the number of children that could attend school. A site for that purpose has been laid off by Mr. Robertson, but as it was considered a little out of the way, the Indians proposed another site that would meet the wishes of everybody. The old day school that was built some years ago was not up to date, they required a larger school and one that would be fully equipped for teaching their children in a proper manner. Mr. Nutty informed me that by keeping the school in operation all summer, that 40 or 50 pupils could be easily induced to attend school, the teacher to take his holidays in the latter part of September and October. There are a hundred children on this reserve of school age, and I think that Mr. Nutty is the first Missionary that has recognised the idea of keeping the school going in the summer, as the only reasonable way of getting the part of these children educated.

The Chief and Band after some deliberation, asked that a day school be built of the following dimensions, and that it be equipped as a day school should be:

My dear Mr. Waddy,

I am writing this in Prince Albert to save time. I was sorry that I missed you in The Pas for I have not seen you since two years ago. However, I thank you for your part in getting me down the line. It means much to me. I met the Dr., and got my mail. Many thanks for that also.

Now about Nelson House School, we have to give up the idea of a Boarding School there at present, so we must do the best we can with the Day School. I think the Department ought to erect a School House which would give some standing to the educational work. In the meantime the Church will be used, of course. Mr. Hutty and Miss Jackson think those dishes can be used to good effect if you will send them out, and if you will secure the necessary food. They will give a hot meal this winter.

Mr. Perrier secured a Miss Winter for Teacher, and she came to The Pas this week expecting to go out, but both Mr. Hutty and Miss Jackson think that in view of the scarcity of canoes and men, the lateness of the season, and the fact that all the people will be away fall fishing for the next six weeks it will be well for the teacher not to go out until the snow comes. Miss Winter has therefore gone back to Brandon to wait till November when she will come in time to catch the train to Mile 137 on the 23rd. November where Mr. Hutty will meet her with a dog team, and see her safely out. She will call and talk matters over with you. Ask the Dr. what he thinks of her. I feel sure she is the right person for the place. I know you will give her all the encouragement possible.

Should there be any change in the train dates please notify Mr. Perrier and Mr. Hutty at once so that there will not be any misunderstanding. Also see that Miss Winter goes to Mile 137.

If there are any other matters please write me. I got those pictures off to Mr. Hutty by the men who brought me out.

Kindest regards,

Sir,

I have the honour to report that Rev. Arthur Barner, Superintendent of Methodist Missions, has asked me if the Department will consider erecting a day school building at Nelson House.

The building used there at the present is the Church, but it is not satisfactory altogether as the children come a long way to school, and the intention is to give a lunch at noon. Such the church people rather object to having cooked in the church. Also they wish to have the school in separate building to give the educational work some standing as distinct from church work.

Up until lately I understood that the Methodist Church intended to start a boarding school at Nelson House, and eventually this is what will be asked for as there are so many children at this point, so if an application for day school is considered it would be waste of money if a boarding school was to be erected in next few years.

No doubt we could carry on a school up at Nelson House, but I think the church people could still let us use their building until the question of a boarding school is decided.

I enclose, herewith, Mr. Barner's letter.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott.

The Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools and Mr. Indian Agent Waddy have, on several occasions, recommended that a day school be built at Nelson House. They make this recommendation because they have been informed that boarding school facilities cannot be provided for some years. On the first ultimo Rev. Mr. Ferrier reported that he had learned the Indians were constructing a log building and he urged the provision of $350 worth of finishing material and the allowing of $500 for freight. Mr. Indian Agent Waddy was asked to report and to make a recommendation. He has intimated that $388.10 will be required for finishing material and that at least $500 will be required for freighting. He recommends that the day school be provided if there is no probability of a residential school in the immediate future.

I wish to recommend that the $388 expenditure be allowed. The Methodist Church have conducted a day school at Nelson House for many years, with practically no assistance from the Department in the matter of capital expenditure.

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose report of visit to the Day School at Nelson House.

The new building is about completed it will be ready for occupation in a few weeks. I supplied what I thought was a sufficient number of windows for the place. I intended them for the side of the school but they only were placed at the back, not allowing enough light for the pupils. It will be necessary to put in two more windows at the side, I beg to request that I be authorised to supply them.

The teacher asks if it would be possible to have storm sash supplied, if so it would require eight.

She also asks for beaverboard to cover the walls above the wainscott. I do not see the need of it myself, but if it is seen in the future that a lining is required for the walls I will take the matter up again.

She also asks for kalsomine for the walls, on the other schools in the Agency we use white wash. The ceiling is shiplap, and the teacher asks if it could be covered with V. Joints. She is living in a pretty cold part of the country so I think this should be supplied, it would require 750 F.B.M. and could be sent in next winter.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 15th instant enclosing the report of your visit to the Nelson House Methodist Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that it is noted that the new building at this point is about ready for occupation. You may arrange to supply two more windows for the side of the building; also to have the eight storm sash supplied. You may also purchase and have supplied the quantity of kalsomine required for the walls of the school building. You should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the windows and the kalsomine.

We are not prepared to authorize the supplying of the beaverboard to cover the walls above the wainscott as the necessity for this is not seen.

If you consider that the 750 F.B.M.of ship-lap should be supplied to cover the ceiling you may arrange for the purchase and forwarding of this quantity at a time most advantageous to having it sent to the school.

Sir,

Report re Annuity Payments, The Pas Man.

DAY SCHOOLS:

At Nelson house, the school building is new, of log walls construction with a good shingled roof, comfortable and is well kept, the teacher is a young man, Charlie Clay by name, he is a clean cut chap who handles his duties very well. He keeps his school and his equipment in fine order. In the holiday season here and also at Split Lake both pupils are not assembled. The improvements I have mentioned for Nelson house extends to the school and its grounds that so the pupils can take exercise during recess hour. I noticed however that a very important necessity is lacking here, proper lavatories have not been provided, this should receive immediate attention, as it provides better sanitary possibilities etc., Dr. Robertson mentions this in his report.

J. K. Bunn,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, October 22, 1925.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Bunn, in a report on the Nelson House Protestant Day School, states he noticed that a very important necessity, viz., proper lavatory accommodation, had not been provided, and that this should receive immediate attention. In connection with this matter, I beg to refer you to previous correspondence. In your letter of January 24th, 1925, you stated as follows:

"The Department gave me instructions to have two toilets built at this place and I gave orders to the H.B. Co. to do the work with the assistance of the teacher. This has upset the teacher very much and there will be some correspondence coming to the Department about it; when the time comes for an explanation from this office it will be supplied."

I may say that we had no correspondence from the teacher with reference to the instructions you gave to have this work done.

If it is not too late this fall, I have to request that you will arrange to have this work carried out. If, however, you consider it too late to have this work carried out, the matter should be drawn to the attention of the Department early next spring. It is thought that suitable toilet accommodation could be erected at a moderate cost.

If the work is completed this fall, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter 128-11-1, dated the 29th ultimo, and further to my letter of recent date in connection with a house belonging to the United Church at Nelson House, which they intend to use as a residence for Mr. Monias, the new teacher.

I was up to Nelson House last week and I found the building the United Church refers to. It was formerly used as a warehouse but has been converted to a residence recently. It needs some repairs and kalsomining as the roofs leaks. The cost of the repairs would be about $50.00. May I please have authority to spend this amount.

As regards the furniture, I think this had better be left until the winter time. It is almost impossible to get furniture into Nelson House during the summer months as the river is so rapid and it has so many portages. The furniture would in all probability be damaged during the journey and the cost would be prohibitive.

Your obedient servant,

September 3rd, 1936

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I have been away at the Western Ontario Leadership Camp and on returning find that Mr. Stewart Monks went into Nelson House single. There is therefore not as much urgency in regard to purchasing furniture for the house which he will occupy as I indicated in my recent conversation with you. If the goods have been shipped, no harm will be done, as his marriage is merely postponed and he will have to set up housekeeping for himself when he arrives at his destination. However, instructions for the purchase of this furniture have not been sent; there is just a possibility that he might be able to borrow enough from the white people in the community to get through the winter.

My conscience tells me that I ought to notify you of this change in plans, though I am rather secretly hoping that the furniture has been purchased and gone forward. I do not regard a bachelor's life in that North country as very desirable - even when he has all the comforts of home.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth Leaton

Oct.21, 1936.

Dear Sir,

I am inclosing herewith voucher No.353 amounting to $72.90 in favour of W.E.W.Hutty, Nelson House, via Wabowien, Man., for material and labour building toilets and repairing school house at Nelson House Reserve.

I made arrangements for this work to be done when I was in at Nelson House in August. I purchased the lumber from S.Donkey, which he had whipsawed himself, and as he was a little short, asked Mr.Hutty to give him the value of the $5.00 in food, which he did while I was there. Mr.Hutty should, of course, obtain a receipt from the Indian and attached to the account. If I wrote back to Nelson House for a receipt it would probably be several months before I got it and possibly would not get it until Spring, as the Indian would be out on his trap line.

I made a verbal agreement with Mr.Hutty for him to build the two toilets and supply the necessary logs for $50.00 and also to chink the school and procure the sand for $15.00.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Samuel Lovell
Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant I regret that the rental of the house at Nelson House was not paid for the period April 1, 1940, to March 31, 1941. I am arranging to have a cheque for $75.00 forwarded to your office next week.

Associate Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
United Church of Canada,
229 Queen St. West,
Toronto 8, Ont.
Ottawa,
September 22, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In official letter of May 3, 1940, you were advised that it had been decided to allow $75.00 a year rental for the house occupied by the teacher of the Nelson House Indian Day School. You forwarded your voucher No. 56 dated May 8, 1940, for payment of the rental for the period April 1, 1939, to March 31, 1940. However, it is noted that you did not forward a voucher at the end of March, 1941. We are arranging for payment of this amount and it will, therefore, not be necessary for you to forward a voucher for the period mentioned but at the end of March each year until further notice you should submit for payment the voucher covering this rent.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. S. Lovell,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
Ottawa, September 11, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Mrs. Mary O. Fay has been nominated by the United Church for the position of teacher at the Nelson House Indian Day School and this nomination has been approved by the Department. We are sending forward herewith the usual questionnaire forms, which should be signed by this teacher and returned to the Department in due course.

Dr. Dorey, in referring to certain repairs that are urgently needed at this school, states:

"The door does not close by more than a full inch at the bottom. The stove is badly broken and there are no storm windows. I think that steps should be taken to remedy this condition at once."

It would be appreciated if you would take the action necessary to have these repairs completed at once. In this connection it might be advisable for you to have a report from time to time on the repairs required at the schools in these outlying and remote districts.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. S. Lovell,

Welfare & Training Division.

PRECIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Requesting authority for the provision of a one-room Indian Day School on the Nelson House Indian Reserve, The Pas Indian Agency in the Province of Manitoba, for which funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates.

Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.
March 6, 1948.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school on the Nelson House Indian Reserve, The Pas Indian Agency, in the Province of Manitoba;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Nelson House Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest..."

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tendering if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely the North American Buildings, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school immediately on a basis of $7,500.00 F.O.B. Winnipeg, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses.

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the provision of this building as
outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.
EX'D.

The committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 6th March, 1948 from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school on the Nelson House Indian Reserve, The Pas Indian Agency, in the Province of Manitoba;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Nelson House Reserve;

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) or pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...";

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building company, namely the North American Buildings, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school immediately on a basis of $7,544.50 F.O.B. Winnipeg, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses;

That it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Honourable
the Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Nelson House Nursing Station,
Nelson House Day School

This will acknowledge your letter of May 21st asking for co-operative scheme in regards to erecting the day school at the time of the erection of our nursing station. I have delayed acknowledging this correspondence until I had thoroughly gone into the matter.

Circumstances with our construction programme are such that I have two carpenters working at Nelson House and am making arrangements to erect the foundation at the same time as the rest of our construction. So that when the erector goes up to erect our nursing station he will also be able to erect your day school. Mr. Law had previously staked out the location for the nursing station and it was shown to me by Mr. Hutty, free trader, in the district with whom our Departments carry on a considerable business and co-operative interests. Mr. Davis was in Norway House last week and we revisited the site and I established the lines of the building and we made arrangements for the excavation to proceed immediately and to obtain suitable stone, gravel and sand for the construction of your school basement. I have advised my carpenters that they are to keep an exact time account of the hours that they spend on either of the above mentioned projects so that the Departmental charges may be correctly distributed. Mr. Hutty is keeping separate accounts for the work done on the day school and the nursing station in regards to the local labour. Carpenters rates are $1.50 per hour each man with board and allowances.

Ottawa, August 30, 1948.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Nelson House U.C. Indian Day School.

On Thursday August 26th I received a long distance phone call from Mr. Conley, Engineer of Indian Health Services concerning the construction of a prefabricated school at Nelson House.

Mr. Conley advised me that he was on his way after visiting at Nelson House, and that the school building was coming along satisfactorily. He had found it necessary to fly in to supervise the work and he would submit a voucher for air transportation accordingly. He has arranged for a carpenter and a painter from the hospital to also do the school. He may have some difficulty with regard to the installation of the furnace though and we will probably hear from Mr. Law concerning this point.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Mr. E. Law,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Mr. Law,

Nelson House Construction

Following conversations with Inspector Davis and Superintendent Neary it has been agreed that as soon as the nursing station at the above point has been completed that the erection will proceed on the erection and finishing of the school. The Department has two carpenters engaged at Nelson House. They have already spent considerable time in the building of the foundation of the school and their services will be transferred for the erection work and finishing of the school. When the painter arrives at Nelson House and has finished painting the nursing station his services will also be transferred to the Affairs Branch for painting the school. It, therefore, is only necessary for you to obtain a heating man to do the installation of the furnaces and heating pipes. We feel you should plan to be present at shortly after September 1st. It would be advisable for you to keep in touch with Mr. John Johnson, North American Buildings Erector who is now on the site and find out when he will commence the erection of the school, and his general progress from time to time at that unit.

On completion of the school the erector and the two carpenters should be brought to The Pas to erect the garage for the doctor. Five Indian labourers should be supplied for this work at The Pas. In view of the fact that this important work is taken the erection goes to Nelson House and because the expenses we expect that you will make the necessary arrangements to bring the erector and two carpenters to The Pas and return them to Norway House. Will you kindly keep in touch with the progress of the work so there will be no delay and their work may be expedited at Norway House. It will be necessary for you to contact Mr. Hughes occasionally in this respect.

Yours very truly,

C.J. Connolly,
Supervising Engineer,
Indian Health Services.
The Director,
Indian Health Services,
Department of National Health & Welfare,
Ottawa.

Attention Dr. W.L. Falconer

Nelson House School

Erection gang carpenters working at Nelson House Nursing Station were employed in connection with the construction of the basement foundation and semi erection of the day school for the Indian Affairs branch at Nelson House on the following dates: July 12th, 13th, 14th, 15th, 16th, 20th, 21st, 26th and August 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 6th, 7th, 9th, 10th, 11th and 12th. I do not anticipate that they will be further engaged this month but on the 1st of September their time may be fully employed with the erector at the school.

Their daily employment is twelve hours at $1.50 per hour and this includes each of two men.

C.J. Connolly,
Supervising Engineer,
Indian Health Services.

NELSON HOUSE SCHOOL

The school was inspected on Oct 5th and found in operation despite the fact that it was not painted. Attendance was so large that the teacher had to make use of the space for the present.

A few minor things were omitted in the finishing but can be taken care of by the staff caretaker or a local indian carpenter. Some of the doors have swelled a bit since the heat has been put on and will have to be dressed down. A couple of lock sets should be replaced. I will take up this matter with the Prefabricators. Inside window stops were not put on in the basement windows and these will be attended to by a local carpenter. I arranged with a local Indian to build a railing around the back porch landing and steps. Arrangements were also made to have the grounds graded and drained.

The glazed door for the basement entry was wrecked in the transportation but was temporarily repaired and will have to be replaced next year. Lowererow of coats hooks should be provided immediately for the small children. A stove for the kitchen, a water cooler and pails should also be provided.

I am told that chemical toilets are being provided for the basement installations this I do NOT recommend as the space provided is not ventilated and does not have a window. The outside facilities could be used for this year and provision made for the above next Spring. Also a mistake was made in placing the doors to the proposed toilets—they are hung backwards, and should be changed before being put into operation.

Mr. Hutty (trader) and the Chief of the Band asked me to request that the Department turn over the old School for Community use. Mr. Hutty was at one time owner of this log building. And supplied frames windows and doors for its completion. Thus he has a personal interest init. He recommends that it should be disposed of 1. as a local community hall 2. as home for a deserving case 3. or to any benefit of the indian reserve but not to a non Indian person.
Would give the above your generous consideration and advise the interested parties.

I wired Mr. Law that the caretaker for the Nursing Station would not have time to look after the School and that he should have someone appointed immediately to make care of the fires and the cleanings. I tried to organize the Indians to clean the windows over the week-end. I hope it was successful. Dustbane should be supplied in ample quantity for sweeping. I requested Mr. Law to send in two kegs immediately.

I expect that Mr. Law has arranged for painters to go in soon. I wired him that they should have the necessary quantity of paint with them on their arrival. Dr. Corrigan removed the paint from the Nursing Station and it will have to be resupplied. I advised Mr. Law to this effect.

I trust the above matters meet with your approval.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your letter of October 15th, file 527-5(EL), regarding painting Nelson House United Church School, the paint for this building has just arrived in The Pas, as Dr. Corrigan flew into Nelson House and took the paint for the school along with that of the Nursing Station to Norway House.

I will be unable to finish the work on this building until after freeze-up. As no authority was given to anyone to use this building before floors and painting was done, however, this school has been in use for sometime now and I do not know the condition of the floors. It is almost impossible to secure a sander in The Pas, so I would like to have authority to have these floors sanded by hand before applying the varnish.

In regards the toilets for the school, I mentioned to you in Winnipeg that new ones were made a year ago for the old school and I would have them moved up to the new school.

In regards to the old school I believe this is an excellent idea in using this for a community centre, as the band on the whole would be benefitted by this, I would suggest that it should be moved near to the sports field before being put in use for this purpose.

Extract from Regional Supervisor Davis' report dated January 4th on the Nelson House U.C. Indian Day School.

The teacher of this school is Miss Ruth Jardine. She appears to me to be more or less untidy and a little sloppy in her methods. However, the school was not in operation when I visited, as it was early in the morning.

Mr. Grafton inspected the school after my visit and I am forwarding his report. There are 43 children on the roll and 25 of school age living around the village who are not attending school owing to a lack of accommodation.

I would recommend that the old school building be repaired and another teacher hired to look after these pupils. I would estimate the cost of repairs at about $250.00. Some desks would be required, but for the time being tables could be erected by Mr. Arnfinson, who is a fairly good carpenter.

Dear Sirs: Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division

Replying to your letter of June 13th, file 527-5 (E.1) in connection with the U.C. Indian Day school at Nelson House,

Teacherage. I understand the original plan was to have the school teacher stay at the Nursing Station. This however, was never put into practice, due to the fact that the nurse in charge did not find this satisfactory. I think in future accommodation for the teachers should be kept in mind in building new schools.

I received word from Nelson House this spring that there was two inches of water in the basement of this school. My Assistant Agent on that Reserve was instructed to drain the basement and level off the ground to provide better drainage from the outside walls. Most of this water I believe drained into the basement from the stairway entrance on the outside of the basement. I would like to inspect this school further before making any suggestions in connection with the two room suite being put in the basement. I will be at Nelson House on my Treaty trip the end of July, and will advise you further on my return.

Toilet accommodation. On my inspection of this school last September while the erectors of this building were still there, I told them that chemical toilets were to be installed in the basement, according to our plans. I pointed out that proper ventilation should be provided for these toilets before they were installed. However, Mr. Connolly visited the school shortly after, and proposed that outside toilets be used. It was after his recommendation that I asked Col. Neary, when attending the Superintendent's Conference...
in Winnipeg, if we could have the outside toilets from the old school, which had been recently built, moved to the new school, as the chemical toilets had not been shipped in. If there is to be a suite in the basement of this school, we will definitely require good ventilation for these toilets. A further check will have to be made to see whether this is possible, and I will include this information in my report, after the Treaty trip.

Your obedient servant,

E. Law
Supt. Indian Agency.

Dear Sirs: Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary
Supt. of Indian Education.

Acknowledging your letter of June 30th, file
527-5 (E), in connection with Nelson House U.C. Indian
Day School.

On a recent visit to this school with our
Regional Supervisor, Mr. R. S. Davis, we discussed the
possibility of installing chemical toilets in the basement
of this school, and we decided against this, as there is
no means of obtaining adequate ventilation now, and there
is a possibility that we might have to build another
classroom in the basement.

We have enough children on this Reserve to fill
two classrooms, but the average attendance is much lower
than it should be. The reason for this is that during
the trapping season the trapper takes all his family to
the trap line, leaving the classroom practically empty for
about two months. Until we make them see the necessity of
leaving their wives and children at home I don't think it
advisable to send materials in for a second classroom in
the basement.

I instructed the Assistant Agent at this point to
put more fill around the basement walls, and this should
prevent further trouble with water in the basement.

I have arranged for the teacher to obtain board
and room with the Assistant Agent at his home, but I am
including in next year's estimates, a small building to be used as a teachersage.

Your obedient servant.

E. Lew
Supt. Indian Agency.

SUBJECT: DATE: July 21, 1959.

Please note comments made in the attached Inspector's Report regarding the condition of the Nelson House U.C. School. Could this matter be given attention?

R. F. Davey
1. SCHOOL BUILDING
Classrooms-number, condition, lighting, ventilation, heating, paintwork; water supply; power; janitor service; basement; cloakrooms.

One classroom in this building.
Condition: classroom - fair
Lighting: fair, more windows needed (see note)
Ventilation: poor
Heating: furnace in basement -
Water supply: lake
Power: none
Basement: very poor, fills up with water every spring and every rainfall.
Cloakroom: hooks and nails on wall of closet

2. PLAYGROUND
Condition, equipment, adequacy.

Public compound and thoroughfare in front of school used as playground. No equipment.

3. TOILET FACILITIES
Lavatories, Wash basins, towels, drinking facilities.

Outhouses: a disgrace (see note)
No washing facilities
No drinking

4. TEACHER'S RESIDENCE
Condition, furniture.

Furnace needs repairs or replacement, seems to be dangerous at present

5. INDUSTRIAL ARTS AND HOME ECONOMICS
Accommodation, condition of plant, tools and equipment, supplies-tools and equipment.

RECOMMENDATIONS

Extension repairs needed:

1. Basement fills with water every spring or even every heavy rain. For the last eight years, nothing has been done, although promised many times. Water from the large field in front of the school passes around the school on its way to the river. It goes through the basement windows and cracks in basement walls and goes out the basement door at the rear when it has reached the door's level (three ft.)

FOR ACTION BY

SCHOOL INSPECTOR

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6241, file 527-5, part 2)
In my opinion, a dike-wall should be built in front of the school and two canals or ditches on each side of the school. (preferably cement) this would stop the water from getting to the school and would allow it to run to the river without passing through the basement. This was recommended seven years ago by a would-be engineer but was never carried out.

2. Lighting: More windows are needed in front. Two windows were recommended 6 yrs. ago. This was approved but somehow only one was installed.

3. No light in vestibules: When outside door and classroom door (inside) are closed, there is complete darkness in the small vestibule. The outside door should be fitted with a window pane.

4. Toilets: They are an absolute disgrace. This is the worst I have seen for many years. Doors have fallen off of their hinges. Very dirty, the sight of them is enough to make a person throw up. (In fact I nearly did.)

5. Washing facilities: At present there is no washing facilities at this school. Washstand, basin, slop pail and reservoir urgently needed.

6. Drinking facilities: At present no drinking facilities.

7. Blackboards at back or room just nailed to wall, no chalk trough.

8. Cloakroom: this consists of hooks and rails on wall of closet. Rod, shelf, hangers type would easily be installed in closet at side of room. (back)

9. Kitchen now being used as a storeroom for books, supplies etc. If shelves put up in front cloakroom closet, all supplies could be stored there.

This could be a nice practical classroom if organized properly. Right now it is not good.

Ottawa, November 26th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, informing the Department that the Nelson House R. C. Indian Day School was opened on the 1st of October, last. We hope that there will be a regular attendance of all the Roman Catholic Indian children of school age at this point.

The Department will approve of the present teacher, Mr. Sicotte, continuing the school in operation during the month of July, 1926, provided there is a regular attendance. If he teaches continuously each school day until the end of July, he will have completed a full teaching year of ten months. This will only allow the month of August, next, as summer holidays, as it is expected the school will reopen again on the 1st of September, 1926. You should inform Mr. Sicotte of the authority granted to continue the school in operation during the month of July, next.

Your obedient servant,

Feb. 10th, 1928.

Re: Nomination for the position of Teacher at Nelson House, Your letter No. 128-18-1.

My Dear Sir:

In behalf of Bishop Charlebois, presently absent, I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd inst. in connection with the nomination of a teacher for Day School at Nelson-House. I understand that the number of children at that post is very few this year. Some of them have become pupils of the Cross-Lake Ind. Res. School and some others have left the place with their parents.

I think this is the only reason why Bishop Charlebois did not ask for the nomination of a teacher to take the place of Mr. Sicotte.

Hoping this will be satisfactory, I remain,

Yours truly,

(SGD.) Martin Lajeunesse, O.M.I., Sec.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Roland Lauze, teacher of the Nelson House R.C. Indian Day School, called upon me on his way back to Nelson House to enquire regarding his salary cheque for the March quarter.

Dear Sir,

May I please be informed what has been allowed in the Estimates under Repairs, Building and Works for Indian Day Schools.

The work and materials I asked for in the estimates are badly required. I particularly want to know if the residence for the teacher at Nelson House R.C. Day School is allowed and also the one for the teacher at Shoal Lake.

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
May 11, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant with reference to providing accommodation for the teacher at the Nelson House R. C. Indian Day School.

An amount of $1200.00 is provided in the current year's appropriation for the above work but it is hoped that the necessary accommodation can be provided at a smaller cost.

I presume that this addition can be erected by day labour employing Indians. Will it be necessary to engage any white men? If so, please let me know what tradesmen will be necessary. An estimate of the cost of the labour should also be supplied. Full details should be furnished regarding the materials as these will have to be ordered through the Purchasing Agent. If any of the material can be purchased close to the school you should state the name of the firm and their address in order that we can give this information to the Purchasing Agent. At the same time you should let me know the best method of shipping the material to the school.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

S. Lovell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Jan 11, 1947

To Mr. Chilson,
Indian Dept.,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

Since last spring I wrote twice for school register and monthly report blanks, and so far haven't received either of them. So, will you kindly send me the above as soon as possible.

The attendance is not too bad this winter considering the intense cold, the bad storms and ailments. Maybe the children would be more enthusiastic to come if we had a decent school.

The present dilapidated building, which we call school, the collapsing leaks, the stove which takes...
a long time to give heat
as it was a broken door
are not things to attract them.

The teacherage, which
is a log affair and never
completed, is just as
cold as an ice box. Last
winter all my potatoes,
ten bags, froze, and this
winter the same thing
happened to the twelve
bags I had and all my
canned vegetables froze also.
To me, it is quite a
loss as the cost of living
is very high up here.

All the pupils whose
allowances had been
suspended now got
their refunds and are
attending a hundred per-
cent.

Yours truly
Roland S. Lange

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of February 12, I beg to advise that I have made a requisition in my estimates for the last three years, to try to get a new school at this point. Owing to lack of authority from the Department to go ahead, I have not been able to do much except keep it in the best of repair, without spending too much money. I received authority from the Department in 1946 to put siding on the teacherage, but found it impossible to buy same. I expect to be in Nelson House towards the end of March, and will give this school and teacherage a thorough over-hauling, and will make my recommendations upon my return.

I might add that this teacher, Mr. Leuze, is very dissatisfied with everything in connection with his work, probably due to the fact that his salary is low, and I sincerely think that he should be given an increase.

Hoping this will clear this matter up to your satisfaction, I remain,

Your obedient servant,

S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.

Colonel Reay:

New R.C. School-site at Nelson House:

The missionary weakened his case a little by seeming to imply that children from Dog Point homes don't attend so well as those from homes numbered 8 to 19 inclusive. Seven homes would not likely have as many children as twelve homes. He might well have indicated the number of children.

Guy Residential school draws 13 pupils from the Nelson House Band.

It appears, however, to be less than a mile's walk from House #1 around the bay to the new site.

Caution would be necessary to paint the windows properly and to avoid shadow and fire risk from adjacent buildings.

Major Clark states that the missionary has weakened his case a little by implying that children from Dog Point homes do not attend as well as those from homes numbered 8 to 19 inclusive. Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of January 31, 1949, file No. 528-5 (E) regarding the location of the Nelson House R.C. School. I am enclosing copy of a letter from Mr. Law, which is self-explanatory.

Mr. Law has recently visited Nelson House and he suggests putting the school where the old teacherage now stands - which is on the Church property. I am still of the opinion that the school should be put on the reserve at Dog Point. However, as the lumber is on hand at the old teacherage site it would probably be as well to go ahead with the building of the school there.

Dear Mr. Davis:

Acknowledging your letter of February 4, 1949, your file 208-4A, in connection with the location of the Nelson House R.C. day school.

I have just returned from Nelson House, and a lot of the materials for this school have been checked and stored in Mission buildings to protect it from the weather. There is a considerable amount of materials to go in yet. Mr. Launz will forward bills of lading as soon as everything has arrived.

After careful consideration, I would suggest that the new school be located near the old teacherage, where the materials are now stored. At the time when these new materials will be needed it would be next to impossible to secure any means of having them hauled to the location on Dog Point, and the cost would run into hundreds of dollars, as it is only a rough trail. There is no storage space at Dog Point, so they could not be moved in the winter. There are only two teams at Nelson House, one owned by Indians and one by Mr. Hutty. Mr. Hutty requires his full time for his own use, and I doubt if the other team could pull half a load even to Dog Point. I hope you will see my point in considering the high cost of having the materials transferred to the Dog Point location, which is my only reason for preferring the location near the old teacherage.

Please notify me as soon as possible, as I have to have the gravel hauled immediately.
In connection with the information you requested regarding the number of children attending school, from Dog Point on the West, and the Eastern end of the area. This information is not available here, but I could have Mr. Arnfinson forward it to you, if you wish.

Your file returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1949-50 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to complete the erection of a one-room Indian Day School on the Nelson House Indian Reserve, The Pas Indian Agency, in the Province of Manitoba;

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

Dear Mr. Neary:

His Excellency Bishop M. Lajeunesse informs me that there are two vacant buildings close to the new Nelson House Indian Day School: 1) the teachorage, 2) the old School.

Hey Dear Lord Bishop,

I was requested to visit the Sioux Mission on the second of October and on the following day had an interview with some of the principal Indians.

I thought it well to visit the tents and houses on the Reserve and glean as much as possible regarding the small attendance at the day school.

The difficulty was considerably lessened by the fact that I was able to speak directly to the Indians by the aid of our interpreter among them who understood Ojibway, while admitting the fact that the school was badly attended no Indian admitted that the teacher was in any fault. There were, however, numerous reasons offered given why the children not attend. Some said the school was too far away off, some of the children had but scanty clothing, others were needed at certain times to help their parents, and it was hard for smaller ones to come.
to school alone. Some alleged they had tried to induce their children to come to school and had not succeeded.

The Chief was of the opinion that the parents needed urging and he proposed going around among them with his party tomorrow with this object. I imagine this action on the part of the Chief will have the desired effect, as numbers of people have promised to send their children more regularly.

So the school is a very important part of the work at this mission. I regret very much it is not more successful. With the other part of Mr. Houttard's work, I am very well pleased. The attendance of the Indians on Sundays, the neat and tidy way in which improvements have been made in the mission premises, in the past year, and last, but by no means least, the progress made in the language all convince me that Mr. Houttard has qualities that fit him for the position he holds.

And now, my Lord,
that the importance of the school question has been upon both parents and teacher, I trust we shall have better things reported in the near future.

Love, my Lord Bishop,
Sincerely yours,
(ego) R. O'Harra,
Superintendent of Indian Missions

Most Reverend Sir,

As Your Grace is aware the day school on the Oak River reserve was closed in the fall of 1907 on account of lack of attendance.

This is a point where it should be possible to maintain a good day school and the Department is of opinion that one of the features which militated against its successful operation in the past was the combining of the duties of teacher with those of the missionary. There are 121 children of school age on this reserve, many of whom are within a reasonable distance of the school, and it is thought that there should be a good field for an energetic teacher who could devote his or her whole time to the school work. The Department in making this suggestion is reflecting in no way upon the work of the Missionary, whose duties in administering to the spiritual needs of these Indians must be sufficiently onerous without having added to them those of teacher.
