Yours of Jan. 20th, No. II6953/1 is to hand. It has been a great regret to me also that the School at Oak River had to be closed. When I was up there a short time ago I had an interview with some of the leading Indians and asked them to suggest any possible way by which the School could be reopened. They urged what almost every Reserve does, viz., that the only solution was the establishment of a boarding school in their midst. I told them that I did not think that at all practicable, at all events while the School at Ekhorn was in existence. I then broached the question of an "improved Day school". I asked how compulsory education could be carried out and their reply was "by appointing constables on the Reserve of leading Indians".

General Remarks.

The state of affairs among the Indians in the
inspectorate is good from the standpoint of having enough
to eat and drink and good clothes to wear, but I should
like to see more interest taken by the Indians in the
education of their children. The Department of Indian
Affairs is spending a very large sum of money every year
on the day school, and little or no benefit is to be seen.
The teachers, as a rule, are not capable of imparting what
knowledge they possess, and some system of training should
be devised to prevent this waste of the public funds.
The day school on the Oak River reserve is still closed, not for want of pupils, but through the indifference of the Indians on the subject of education. Fourteen of the children are at Elkhorn Industrial School, also a few at the Brandon Industrial School; but there are seventy-two children on the roll of the reserve between the ages of six and fifteen, also twenty-five between fifteen and twenty, leaving say fifty without education owing to negligence on the Indians' part.

On the Oak Lake reserve there are about twenty school children who do not go to school. Birtle Indian Boarding School, they say, is too far away, and being Presbyterian, they are, through the influence of the lay-reader, kept from the Elkhorn School, which is less than forty miles from the reserve. The heads of the Presbyterian Indian work informed me that they will make a special effort to get these children to the Birtle Indian Boarding School as soon as their addition is finished.

Mr. Pedley,

In reference to Mr. Aikins' letter of the 30th ultimo to the Minister in regard to the need of a school on the Oak River Reserve at Griswold (Sioux) I beg to say that there was a day school in operation on this reserve for many years prior to 1908, when it was closed on account of the very unsatisfactory attendance, the average having dwindled down to one while the Rev. Mr. Maggrah was in charge.

This school was carried on under the auspices of the Church of England and continued for some years after it should have been closed for want of attendance.

The Department was in frequent correspondence with the church authorities regarding this school before it was closed and after that the correspondence was kept up with a view to having it re-opened under a competent teacher.

In June, 1911, the Archbishop of Rupert's Land suggested the engagement of Mrs. Maggrah, wife of the missionary
missionary, as teacher for this school. She was offered an initial salary of $300.00, which she declined, saying that unless she was paid an initial salary of $500.00 per annum she would not accept the position. The Department informed Mrs. Maggrah that it was not disposed to pay her that amount, as she was not a qualified teacher.

Archbishop Matheson was then informed that, in view of the fact that the opening of this school was at best only an experiment and that as Mrs. Maggrah's qualifications were hardly satisfactory, it was considered advisable to continue the efforts to recruit children from this reserve for the Elkhorn and other industrial schools.

There are enough children on the reserve of school age to justify a day school being maintained there, if a competent teacher could be placed in charge, and the Department has signified its willingness to pay a fair salary to a qualified teacher, but past experience has shown that it is simply a waste of money to carry on the school with the class of teachers furnished by the church authorities.

MEMORANDUM OF INSTRUCTIONS FOR FIELD MATRONS ON INDIAN RESERVES

1.—Much of the ill health among Indians grows out of overcrowding in their small houses. Whenever more than two persons occupy space less than $10 \times 10 \times 10$ feet for each person, you should report matters to the office of the Indian Agent. You should urge upon the Indians the necessity of proper ventilation and the admission of fresh air by such means as are available. The Indians should also be advised against the practice of frequent overcrowding due to visiting.

2.—As the excessive infant mortality arises so frequently from artificial feeding, it is essential that mothers equipped with means to nurse their children. But as nutrition is essential to health, careful inquiry must be made in all cases where artificial feeding is utilized. Cow's fresh milk ought to be always available, but it is essential that it is served in clean utensils. It may be boiled, then be heated and kept the air several times into the can or well standing in cool water. Thereafter it must be placed in a box kept in ice or in a cellar or other cool place away from flies. It is equally essential that feeding bottles be replaced by a clean tin for the milk, and that special feeding utensils be provided. The dangers of giving cracked bread or other scarcely food until three months after birth, ought especially to be impressed on mothers.

3.—As personal cleanliness is very gradually learned, the mother is to be taught this especially for the sake of her child. The dangers of eye infection at birth (ophthalmia neonatorum) ought to be especially taught, and a warm solution of boracic acid used for cleansing the eyes for the first days after birth. This may be applied with good effect by pointing to individual cases of blindness in the band dating from birth. Similarly the daily bath for the baby, always in a warm room, must be insisted upon, and incidentally the keeping a supply of clean clothes for the baby should be urged.

4.—As the child grows he is able to play on the floor, and danger results from the dirt on the floor with tuberculosis infections too often prevalent in the small, badly kept houses. The duty first is to urge constantly the scrubbing and cleaning of floors, and for the baby it is essential that a clean sheet or rug be placed where it can creep about, so that it does not come into the dirt on the floor. It is certain that the tubercular infection is transmitted thus rather than any other way.

5.—When the child is running about, the dangers are lessened in a degree, as he can get into the fresh air; but it is the general experience that the next great danger to the infant is when contagious diseases, as measles or whooping cough, occur. The mother is too often ignorant of the nature of these diseases, and the first sickness is generally allowed out of bed only to die from supervening pneumonia due to cold and exposure. You should insist on these children being kept in bed until the bronchitis and cough have passed in measles, and during the feverish stage of whooping cough. When scarlet fever or diptheria occurs, insist on a physician being called.

As you may be at a distance from a medical officer, it is well to know that parasitic diseases, such as pediculi and ringworm, are liable to affect the school children. For such cases a mixture of tallow calamine and salicylic acid of quick lime and sulphur in parts of 1 to 1, and boil them well for two hours and then work them into an ointment with fresh fat, if no vaseline can be procured. For cockroaches in houses, sprinkle borax generously around the cracks of the floor and see that bedsteads are carefully cleaned with oil if they become affected.

6.—Practical instruction should be given when possible in plain cooking, sewing, washing and the cutting and mending of garments, as well as other branches of knowledge essential to proper management of a home.

7.—These are hints that will prove of much value when each Field Matron succeeds in gaining, through kindly interest, the confidence of the housekeeper. Through such visiting the teacher will succeed in getting parents to see that their children attend school regularly.

8.—You should keep a diary and you will be expected to make monthly reports showing the nature and extent of duties performed. This report should be forwarded through the office of the Indian Agent.

DUNCAN C. SCOTT,
DEPUTY SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL OF INDIAN AFFAIRS.

Dear Sir,

Your letter # II6,953-I of the 9th Inst to hand re Mabel Wasuda.

As soon as it was reported to me that this child had gone to Qu Appelle School I sent for Mrs Wasuda to come to the Office on the Reserve and she came.

She did not seem to be deeply agitated when I saw her.

I asked her if she had given the Grandmother authority to take the child to Qu Appelle School; she said they had been talking about it some time before and she did not want her to go.

These are a few questions I asked her.

Q. Are you a member of the English Church on the Reserve.
A. No, but I attend there sometimes and Mabel was baptised in the English Church on the Reserve.

Q. What Church do you belong to?
A. Presbyterian.

Q. What School do you want your child to go to when she is old enough?
A. Portage la Prairie Boarding School; where I was educated myself.

I think there has been a lot of unnecessary excitement in regard to this.

I do not know of any interference by the Priest with the Oak River Day School except that this girl was a Pupil there.

As soon as I found out she had left the Reserve I did all in my power to have her returned. It was the Grandmother who took the child; not the Priest.
I expect this child will be returned to the Reserve shortly and I will see that the Mother of the child looks after her. This child was going to the Oak River Day School and was getting along well. I think some notice should be given to the Teacher or Agent before they are taken away.

The Teacher, Mrs. McDonald and myself have done our best to make the School a success but we are the only ones who are working for it on the Reserve.

Since the authorities at Qu'Appelle have decided to return this girl I do not see what more we can do about it.

The present age, he said, was an age of mental unrest. Many circumstances were in mental distress. For such people there was only real comforter, but it was necessary that they should turn their hearts to Him if they were to obtain that comfort which He offers. There was no other source of real comfort in the world which could provide relief.

Again and always blind, Dr. Peck gave a missionary message in which he declared that God had called him to preach Christ. That mandate must be known His marvelous works. Today, he said, the world's greatest need was the Savior. The most monumental work among the Indians would be done by the church because they had never improved the situation. If the church did not succeed, he said, as it had in the past, surely Bishop Reeves deals with Christ's commandment to His church to go into all the world and preach the gospel. The church had been, to some extent, successful in its activities and to some extent had tried to carry out its mission. The missionary work, however, had been done by those who had been given the same power which had enabled the Jewish church to carry the message from different nations was manifest today. The church must have the desire to learn the Indian language and culture in order to reach the people of the north.

In about 120 years, he said, much had been accomplished in Western Canada. In 1874, when he came, there was not a single Christian Indian, while today there are thousands of Christians. For the work which had been accomplished, he said, he was thankful. The Church of England had been the first to bring Christianity to the north than any other missionary organization. Much had been achieved, he said, but the present work must be continued. The Forward Movement would be carried on by the church with new objectives, and the present day members of the church must be prepared to meet their responsibilities if the church is to continue to exist.

Rev. Canon B. W. Heeney, of St. John's Anglican Church, spoke briefly, emphasizing the importance of the Christian church to obtain the spiritual welfare of the Indians. He said, "If the church does not pick up the Indians, something being done, the government will take over." He then introduced Rev. J. F. Ahenakew, who said that he came to Manitoba in 1874, being one of the first three Indians sent by the Anglican church to go to Saskatchewan and the Red River district. He was also the author of the well-known book, "Red Indians of Canada." He said, "I have spent my whole life in missionary work among the natives. I have translated much translation work during my missionary career, including the Bible and other northern points."

He then spoke of the remarkable development of the Anglican church in Western Canada, since he started his work 139 miles north of Edmonton. In those days, he said, he had to supervise the work of the church throughout the whole of Alberta and Saskatchewan, while today, these provinces are divided into three dioceses, having three bishops and an archbishop.

At the Sunday school service in the afternoon, Dr. Peck took an active part in the morning service addressed by Mr. Ahenakew. An interesting feature of this service was the singing of hymns by the Indians present quoted or sang the hymn, "Jesus, Lord of All," in several different Indian dialects.

Mr. Ahenakew is in the city to attend the Anglican centenary celebration. He said he would visit Holy Trinity church some time this week. He said he intended to continue his study of medicine, as he intended to serve the Indians in the capacity of a medical missionary.

Sir,

With reference to letter # I33-3-I dated November 23rd 1920 I have the honor to inform you that this is three different notices of three different Teachers for the Oak River Reserve since July 1920 and if the Church had had all their own way there would have been no School there since July 1st.

Is it a sure thing this time?

There is only about a months supply of coal at the School and coal is hard to get, I put in all the coal I could secure at that time but owing to the uncertainty of things I did not know if the School would be opened this Winter or not.

Rev Canon Jeffery was here on Sunday and I asked him to let Archdeacon Thomas know the circumstances in regard to the coal.

There was a car of coal in this morning and I went down to the Dealer; he informed me that he had more orders to fill than he had coal.

I think it would be just as well to leave the School closed until Spring as it is hard to get the children to attend School in the Winter.

Referring to the last paragraph of your letter; I have done everything in my power to help this School both in time and money; the citizens of the District were proud of the School and the way it was handled and it reflected great credit on the Department. I think if you will look up the reports of the Teacher the Missionary has not been more than four times a year to visit the School for the last
three years, they took absolutely no interest in it at all; after all the time and trouble I have taken with this School I hate to see it turn out to be a failure, and they got rid of the best Teacher they will ever have; naturally I feel sore at the way things have turned out.

Another thing, Miss Havard was Teacher for the last six years and she advanced the children faster in one year than three years than she did the three years previous because she understood the Indians and knew how to handle the children.

Does the new Teacher undertake to keep the School clean and are the children to have their hot dinner? I understand he is a single man.

I am inclosing a clipping from the Winnipeg Free Press, his statements and mine do not tally for I have found the Department do the work and supply the money and the Church have done nothing to speak of at least, in this Agency.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Sir,

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 19th ultimo concerning the Oak River Indian Day School, and asking if there is any reason why the school building on the reserve should not be used by Mr. Hyson, the teacher lately appointed.

In reply I beg to state that the information available from the files is that the school building was erected in 1892. In 1913 the Department decided to use the church basement rather than repair the old school house. This course of action was never taken, because immediately after Mr. Agent McDonald into the town of Griswold. This released the agency buildings which have been in use for school purposes until last year, when the Agent was returned to live on the reserve.

Last year Mr. Agent McDonald stated to the church authorities that the old school building was cold and not fit for use, so we suggested that school be held in the basement of the church. As no teacher was available at this time, this plan was never completed. This year, when the school was opened for the summer months, Mr. Agent McDonald advised against using the church basement on the grounds that it would not be a healthy place for studying, and he and the church authorities recommended to the Department that we use two rooms in the missionary's home.

The Superintendent of Indian Education visited the Oak River reserve this summer, and found the school being conducted fairly satisfactorily in the missionary's home. Mr. Hyson who was moved from the Fairford reserve, understood that two rooms, which open into each other in the missionary's home, were to be used for school purposes.

The Indians do not appear to be friendly disposed towards Mr. Hyson and his family and I understand that threats have been made by them not to allow their children to attend the school while Mr. Hyson was the teacher there. I did not investigate this matter as Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Education, had arranged to visit the reserve for the purpose of looking into the complaint made against Mr. Hyson. Several Indians told me that the Hyson family looked upon Indians as if they were no better than dogs, and after staying at the school for two nights I came to the conclusion that Mr. & Mrs. Hyson and their daughter, a young lady of about 19 years of age, were not in sympathy with the Indians, and it is undoubtedly a mistake for these people to be engaged in Indian work. I believe since my visit to the school that Mr. Hyson has been transferred to the Griswold Agency, but unless he and his family become more sympathetic towards and tolerant with the Indians, he will meet with no more success there than he did on the Fairford reserve.
I would particularly draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks in regard to Mr. Hyson, the school teacher, who has been transferred to the Griawold Agency. I may say that I have heard from different sources that Mr. Hyson is not the proper type of man to be engaged in Indian work, and I was sorry to see that he had been transferred, as in my opinion he should not have been retained in the service of the Department.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the Oak River Day School in the Griswold Agency, which I visited on the 13th instant.

The classroom is in the Missionary's residence on the reserve, where what was intended for a dining-room and sitting-room, with an arch between, is used for this purpose. The room is fairly large and is well lighted and provided with good ventilation. A large window in the East, two in the South, and one in the West side of the room provide good light. An ample supply of single desks is provided for the number of pupils enrolled.

Mr. A. Hyson is in charge as teacher. He has had 23 years experience in England, and 13 years in Canada, but does not hold a certificate for Manitoba. There are 22 pupils enrolled; 11 boys and 11 girls. The average attendance for the past five months has been slightly over 63% of the enrollment. All the pupils are in the lower standards; 17 in Standard 1, and 5 in Standard 2. The attendance is very irregular and as a consequence

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Saskatchewan.
Inspector Murison's Report on the Oak River Day School

as a consequence the progress is not satisfactory, to my mind. There is, in my opinion, no good reason why the attendance should not be good at this school. The distance from the school at which the children reside is not greater than at Little Pines or Cote reserves, and other points where we are getting a much more satisfactory attendance. This is attributable, I am fully convinced, to indifference on the part of the parents. There were only eight children present on the day of my visit, although the parents had been notified the previous day that I was going to visit the school. In view of there being two residential schools within thirty miles of this reserve, viz:- Brandon and Elkhorn, to which the Protestant children could be sent, and the Qu'Appelle School at Lebret, which can be reached direct by railway, to which the children of Roman Catholic parents could be sent without imposing any hardship on the parents, I am of the opinion that the Department would be justified in closing this school, and insisting on the compulsory attendance of the children who are physically fit at the residential schools. There are 71 children in the Band from six to fifteen years of age, and only nineteen of these are in attendance at residential schools. Apart from these and the 22 enrolled at the Day School there are 30 of school age who have never attended any school. Of course there are a few who are physically unfit, but the number is small. I have been visiting this school for the past six years, and have brought the importance of providing the children with an education to the attention of the parents. They, however, appear to have no sense of responsibility.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the Day School of the Griswold Agency.

The school is held in the Mission House owned by the Church of England. The two rooms on the South side of the house have been taken for class-rooms. These rooms are well lit, but an archway separates the two rooms, allowing only two rows of seats to extend the full length of the rooms. The other rows of seats are broke by the projection of the arch on either side.

The blackboard is not at the front of the children but on the side wall, and consists of a piece about 8 ft. long. On account of the arch, the board can only be seen by those in the front half of the school. Those behind the arch can see very little, some not at all.

At present there are 25 on roll. The day I attended, there was 6 present. The average attendance for quarter ending September 30th, was 17.8; for that ending June 30th - 12.6. There are seven or eight children on the reserve of school age, not attending school, which should not be the case. These added would bring the roll up to 33.

All these pupils are either in grade 1 or 2, and range from 8 to 13 yrs. of age, which figures do not speak well of advancement made. The parents of many of these children are away much of the time in summer, and consequently the children are with them instead of being at school.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
being at school. Then in the winter, some have as far as 3½ miles to come and many are really not physically fit to walk this distance, with the result that perhaps they come one day and stay home the next. Then again, only odd Indians have time pieces, so that the children come to school any time from 8 to 11 A.M. They can't help it because they do not know the time. Under these conditions and with boarding schools as close as Brandon and Elkhorn and Lebret, it seems to me the only solution, whereby their children may have a decent education is to close the Day School and move these children to boarding schools. They would then be able to attend regularly the class-rooms, and also receive attention for any of their physical ailments.

Mr. Hysen is the teacher, and it looked to me as if he was just as satisfied if 6 were present as 20. He is an old man and entirely out of date, and I doubt if under the best of attendance, much progress would be made.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

In addition to obtaining these figures, the accuracy of which can be relied upon as they came from the books of Mr Clarke, the very excellent Indian Agent, I also carefully investigated the management of the School, and endeavoured to form a just estimate of the qualification and ability of Mr Hyson to properly discharge his duties. My conclusions are as follows, namely—

(1) There is essential need for the continuance of the Day School at Oak River, and that if the said School is efficiently conducted it can be, and I trust will be, one of the largest Day Schools in the West.

(2) That there are too many children of school age (71) and too great a number closely following in their wake (54) to depend on their absorption into the Residential Schools.

(3) That the present enrollment and average attendance is an evidence of the inability on the part of Mr Hyson to attract the pupils to the School, or to interest and instruct them when they are in attendance.

I beg leave, therefore, respectfully to recommend that the Indian Day School at Oak River be retained. That the services of Mr Hyson be discontinued at the end of the present school year. That a qualified Teacher be appointed to succeed him, and that the said Teacher be a married man whose wife shall be required to take the Junior Class.

I shall count it a privilege to be permitted to nominate such a man, and will assist in every possible way to promote the success of the work.

I am,

Very faithfully yours,

My dear Sir:-

I very greatly regret that the increased duties of the Christmas season have delayed the sending of a report on my visit to the above School.

In accordance with my letter of December the 1st, I visited the Sioux Reserve and went most carefully into its educational problems. I interviewed the Teacher, then the Agent, and last of all I talked with some of the leading Indians on the Reservation.

The following is the result of my inquiry, and upon which I base my subsequent recommendation:-

(1) The population of the Reserve, as given in the Census of 1926, is three hundred and six souls. Of this number seventy-five per cent are members of the Anglican Church, and of the remaining twenty-five percent nine families are Roman Catholic, and the rest Pagan.

(2) There are resident on the Reserve 125 children between the ages of 1 and 15 years. Of this number 54 are under the age of 6 years, and 71 are between the ages of 6 and 15 years. In addition there are 26 children in Residential Schools, namely- Elkhorn, Brandon, Portage, Le Frette.

(3) From the School Register I gathered that the present enrollment in the School is 24, being made up of 17 boys and 7 girls, and that the daily average attendance is about 15.

I reported on conditions here last fall, and with the attendance at such a low ebb during this inspection, it is impossible to state whether any progress has been made or not. However, I might add that many of the children have yet to learn to speak English, so that in view of such a condition, progress is slow. I am of the opinion that little effort is exercised, except by the Agent, in trying to secure a fair attendance. In spite of having a day school on the reserve for so many years, little progress has been made, and I have no doubt this has been partly due to the fact that the children attend very irregularly. I still feel, as I stated in my last report, that the only remedy is to close this school and send the children to boarding schools. This would entail no great hardship on the parents, as the schools are close and can be easily visited. It would allow the children to be in regular attendance, without having to endure so much cold weather with perhaps insufficient clothing and lack of proper food.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on
the Oak River Day School, inspected on December 11th, 1930.

There is no school building at this
point, and the classroom work is carried on in the
Missionary's house. The room used is not suitable as
the lighting is poor, and ventilation bad.

The roll calls for 24 pupils - 12 boys
and 12 girls, and I found 12 children present. The
attendance is irregular, and I noticed that some of the
pupils were very late. The average for September was 11,
for October 10, and for November 12. The grades are
arranged as follows:

Grade I - 16
II - 4
III - 4

This is the first time I have visited
this school since Miss Stapleton took charge, and
undoubtedly some progress has been made. The children
read fairly well, and their book work was tidy and
clean. The children sing a number of songs, and are
much brighter and more alert than when last inspected.
If the pupils could be made to attend more regularly,
I believe progress could be accomplished.

The children are made to wash on arrival,
and also before lunch is served at noon. They were
clean and

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
clean and tidy in appearance.

A noon-day meal of porridge, cocoa, and biscuits is provided for the children. I noticed they are not fond of the porridge, and I think if vegetable soup could be substituted for the porridge, it would be appreciated.

At present there are a number of children who attend school very irregularly, while others are not even enrolled. I doubt if these children can be recruited for Elkhorn or Lebret without police assistance. I talked to most of the parents, and in the majority of cases they expressed willingness to send the children to Brandon. These Indians often drive to Brandon, and could no doubt more often see their children if enrolled there. The fact that they are not allowed to send the children to Brandon makes them more determined not to allow them to attend any boarding school. Some of the children have long distances to come, and will never be regular attendants at day school. The following is a list of the children and their ages as near as I could obtain:

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report of an inspection at the Oak River Day School, which was made by Mr. Hamilton on December 11th.

You will note that the register at this school calls for a pupilage of 24, but that the average attendance is between 11 and 12. It seems to me that if this does not improve we should take steps to send the Protestant children from this reserve either to Elkhorn or Brandon, and the Roman Catholic children to Lebret. There is accommodation at all these schools, and I do not see why this condition should be allowed to exist on the reserve. I am writing to the Agent, instructing him to see these Indians at once and advise them that if there is no improvement in the attendance of their children at Day School they will be sent to Boarding School.

(4) Unquestionably, the teacher, Deaconess Stapleton, is held in high esteem and affection by the people. Last year, owing to her enforced absence from the school through an attack of typhoid fever, progress was much hindered, but she has now fully recovered. In addition to her teaching duties her voluntary ministrations as a qualified Nurse increases the bond between herself and the people and, should the school close the Reserve will lose one whose work and influence is a potent factor in the harmony of the place. For twenty-three years she has worked amongst our Indians in the West and is regarded by all as one of their best friends.

These, I think, are the main features to be considered in the case, and while I fully recognize the necessity upon the Department, in these difficult times, to effect economy in every possible direction, yet I recommend and urge that the work at the Oak River Day School be permitted to continue, even though it may have to be done at a further reduced salary. I am confident from all I can gather that the closing of the School would react most detrimentally upon the Indians on the Reserve, and I earnestly hope in their behalf that the Department will not find it necessary to take the proposed step.

I am,

Faithfully yours,

March 6, 1933.

Re: Oak River Indian Day School.

My dear Sir:

I regret the delay in replying to yours of December 21st regarding the proposal to close the above Indian Day School at the end of June.

The whole subject bears so vitally on the well-being of the Reserve and the contentment of its people, that I felt it was most desirable for me to confer with the Agent, the teacher, and some of the leading members of the Band before attempting to give my considered opinion on the proposal made. I was able during the past week to visit the Reserve and now respectfully submit the main features of the case for your consideration.

(1) There are 82 children on the Reserve at this date, and of this number—

12 are on the School Roll.
7 are of school age and will shortly attend.
9 will reach school age next year.
7 in the year following.
47 younger children of ages between infancy and five years.

(2) The average attendance during the past few months has been only a fraction over five, but it is generally acknowledged that this is due to the exceptionally severe winter we have had in the West. Some of the children living at a distance of two miles and more from the School.

(3) There is, I find, an antipathy on the part of the parents to send their children to the Residential Schools before they have reached at least the age of 10, except in the cases of orphans and children in destitute homes.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I have the honor to inform you that with reference to the enclosed Quarterly School Return I see that Mr Hysen has put the Government Grant towards the Teachers Salary as $240-00 whereas your letter No 133-3-I dated August 14th 1922 states that Mr Hysen's Salary will be $800-00 per year, if there has been any raise since that date I have not heard of it.

There were a few of the School Children had bad colds and one was very ill with pneumonia.

Your obedient servant

Jas M. Donald.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa. April 6, 1923.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 31st ultimo, I beg to say that the salary of Mr. Hyson, teacher of the Oak River Indian Day School, who began duties at this school on September 1st, last, is $800.00 a year.

As there are ten teaching months in the year, Mr. Hyson was paid 1/10 of his yearly salary for the month of September, or, $80.00, and 3/10 of his yearly salary, or, $240.00 for the December quarter.

For your information I may say that, commencing with September 1, 1923, all teachers of Indian day schools will be paid in the same manner.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Jas. McDonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, June 20, 1927.

Sir:

Referring to official letter of the 15th ultimo, I beg to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Brandon has nominated the services of Deaconess Winifred Stapleton as teacher of the Oak River Sioux Indian Day School to succeed Mr. A. Hyson. Miss Stapleton is at present teacher in an Indian school on the Peguis Reserve. The Department is approving of her transfer to the Oak River Sioux Indian Day School to begin duties when the school reopens after the summer holidays, on or about September 1st, next. The salary that will be allowed her is at the rate of $30 per teaching month.

I shall be pleased if you will give Miss Stapleton every assistance you can when she takes up duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT from Indian Agent Clarke's Report for the Month of January, 1932, regarding the OAE RIVER SIOUX INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Original on File 133-3-7.

The school was closed one week from 4th to 10th January, owing to Miss Stapleton being laid up with an attack of Typhoid Fever and schoolroom was fumigated and scrubbed out during this week. School room opened on the 11th and Miss Wilkins substituted Miss Stapleton as teacher for remainder of month and Miss Lauder is substituting Miss Wilkins as janitor.

On advice from her doctor, Miss Stapleton is contemplating taking a trip and her partner Miss Wilkins, is willing to carry out her duties whilst she is away.
Ottawa, February 5, 1932.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the first instant, informing the Department of the illness of Deaconess Stapleton, teacher of the Oak River Indian Day School. It is noted that Miss Stapleton will require a rest from her duties in order that she can recuperate.

The Department has approved of leave of absence for Miss Stapleton and will allow her salary until April 30th, next. Approval is granted for Miss Wilkins, who has acted as janitor and assistant, to perform the duties as teacher during the absence of Miss Stapleton. We were informed that the arrangements for the carrying on of the work by Miss Wilkins were made by Miss Stapleton, and, as our funds this year are extremely limited, there will be no increase in salary to Miss Wilkins for the period she acts as substitute teacher. It is understood that, besides the teaching duties, she will continue her work as janitor and preparing and serving the pupils' midday lunch.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Russell F. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Right Rev. W. Thomas, D.D.,
Bishop of Brandon,
Brandon, Man.

Ottawa, 16 January 1892

Mr. [Name],

I have examined the plans for school buildings submitted by Mr. [Name] and find them very good for small schools. These buildings would accommodate approximately 27 children each. The children at the Oak River School number in all 17, so the attendance only 77%. The present building could properly speaking only have air space for 9 children.

The cost of the school office, high averaging $5 per foot of course in certain places but west it is difficult to put lumber or other material without paying a high price for it. At a rough estimate I think the cost per cubic foot should build these schools not over $343.20 for the structure.

As regards the comparison of the plans I would state that the school plans prepared in this Department were done so with the view to economy as well as to give an a much better structure than generally built in the interior portions of the country and along the river lines.

Specifications for

Building to be erected on the
Oak River Sioux Indian Reserve.

Walls. To be of balloon frame construction 10 feet 6 inches in height; studs 2 inches by 4 inches at 16 inch centers spaced and sided with two Patent or Tar Paper between, sills 6 inches by 6 inches.

Roof. To be half pitch. Purlins 2 inches by 6 inches. Collar ties 2 inches by 4 inches (all 16 inch centers) Shingles closed with planks on one side lumber, fastened with either tar or two patent paper and shingled. Shingles to be placed 4 inches to the weather and each shingle nailed with not less than two nails. Heat box cornice to be put on. Rafter and collar ties to be placed.

Floor. Joists 5 inches by 8 inches at 16 inch centers. Framed and framed to be blind nailed and closely pointed.

Windows and doors. To be fitted with storm on plan and of the dimensions shown. Doors to have good strong butt hinges with extra heavy locks.

Posture for porch. To be raised 6 inches above the floor.

Nails inside. To be wainscoted with planed lumber 4 feet 6 inches high with cap and upon back of wall to be well sealed with planed lumber.

Chimney.
Chimney - To be built of brick on a good stone foundation five inches deep, so as to come on top six inches and have a hole for pipe to be laid in connection into stove fitted with a chimney ring.

Foundation for building - To be concrete stones that may be taken on and solidly placed and not run from butt against and centre of wall under the floor to be well supported.

J. Asquith - Indian Agent

Honourable J. A. Glen, P.C., M.P.,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Glen:

During the recess I left with Canon I. A. Norris, of Brandon, the reports of the meetings of the Committee on Indian Affairs. He had not had the opportunity previously of reading these reports and some other literature.

Canon Norris has now returned them to me and in an accompanying letter he refers to the handicap under which the Mission at Griswold Reserve is working as a result of there being no school building on the reserve. As it is, they are using a small room in the Mission House. I visited the Reserve in October last and was in this room which is much too small and altogether inadequate. It was merely a sort of excuse for a school.

Canon Norris urges that some provision be made in this regard and he suggests that possibly a building could be secured and moved to the Reserve from the airport at North Brandon or from Souris. Personally I think the suggestion would be well worth considering.

The buildings at the Brandon airport were for quite a while under the disposal of the Central Housing and Mortgage Company but I understand they are now turned back to War Assets. The buildings at Souris were taken over by the Province, it having first priority after the Depts.

When you are less rushed than you are at present, if that time should ever occur, I will be glad to discuss this matter personally.

Yours sincerely,

J. E. Matthews, M.P.

I wish to acknowledge your letter together with a copy of one from Mr. J. E. Matthews, M.P., Brandon. For your information I attach a copy of a letter from Mr. Young concerning this matter.

I agree with Mr. Matthews and with Mr. Young that provision should be made, without delay, for a Day School on the Oak River Reserve. I think it would be difficult to move a suitable building such a long distance and, of course, the bridge over the Assiniboine River presents a real obstacle. I think Mr. Young is right when he says the building would have to be dismantled.

Re your letter 204-11A dated February 24, 1947:

I certainly agree that a school building is needed on the Oak River Reserve.

I am doubtful if a suitable building could be moved from either Souris or Brandon Airports, due to the fact that it would have to come through one of the Assiniboine bridges. These bridges are overhead structure, and would not permit a building of any height or size to be moved through them. It would be necessary to dismantle and rebuild if airport buildings were used.

I have not been able as yet to purchase new lumber to repair Indian homes or build an implement shed, but I do note that contractors seem to be able to procure lumber for their projects.

I believe that if the Department called for tenders for the erection of a Day School on the Oak River Reserve, that a contractor would be able to secure the lumber and erect a building.

Ottawa, March 7, 1947.

Dear Mr. Bean:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 17, concerning the educational facilities on the Griswold Reserve.

It is our intention to build a number of Indian day schools and teachers' residences in Manitoba during the 1947-48 fiscal year. I have written to Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba, concerning your proposal that we might move one of the former R.C.A.F. buildings at Brandon to the reserve for use as a school. You will be interested to know that at Stratford we are now using three former army buildings as schools and that they have proved very satisfactory.

However, the main difficulty according to Mr. Hamilton would be that the buildings would have to be moved through one of the Assiniboine bridges. Unfortunately, these bridges are overhead structures and would not permit a building of any height or size to be moved through them. Therefore it would be necessary to dismantle and rebuild the entire structure. As we would have also the additional expense of excavating the basement, putting in cement foundations, erecting the chimney, etc., it is unlikely that we would save much money or have a sound building in this event.

The building situation will largely determine the locations of the schools to be built this year in Manitoba. There are many places in urgent need of such day schools and

J. H. Matthews, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,

Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba, concerning your proposal that we might move one of the former R.C.A.F. buildings at Brandon to the reserve for use as a school. You will be interested to know that at Brentford we are now using three former army buildings as schools and that they have proved very satisfactory.

However, the main difficulty according to Mr. Hamilton would be that the buildings would have to be moved through one of the Assiniboine bridges. Unfortunately, these bridges are overhead structures and would not permit a building of any height or size to be moved through them. Therefore it would be necessary to dismantle and rebuild the entire structure. As we would have also the additional expense of excavating the basement, putting in cement foundations, erecting the chimney, etc., it is unlikely that we could save much money or have a sound building in this event.

Dear Mr. Matthews,

I am much obliged for your kind letter of the 15th instant, and hasten to say that I am already in receipt of the reports of the Committee held during this session. However I should be grateful to receive a copy of the Indian Act in order that I may get acquainted with the affairs of the Indian, and be in a better position to advise them.

I was very pleased to note in your report about the need of a school on the reserve, and I sincerely hope the Dept. will make a good effort to build it this year. For really it is impossible to continue the school in my house. At present we have 19 pupils crowded in one room, and we have had 21 which meant that I had to use a part of my dining room to accommodate them. The smell of the children has just about sickened us all when the house has been warm, and it is very embarrassing when entertaining our guests. I also note from past records that the Dept. have not made any provision to provide sanitary arrangements for the children, and every year this has come out of our Mission funds. Just now both conveniences are in a dilapidated condition, and really unfit to be used but I have no funds available to meet this expense.

This letter is not meant to take the form of a complaint, but a bare statement of facts which I feel you will be interested to have in your hand as a support or any motion you might make to the Dept. for the erection of a school.
I further understand from the Agent that whilst we are going to lose six pupils this fall, we may expect twelve new entrants for our term in September.

My wife and I are looking forward to a visit from you whenever you are in Brandon and are able to visit us.

With all good wishes,

Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd.) Albert E. Kemp.

Dear Mr Neary:

I am instructed by the Executive Committee of the Diocese of Brandon to make application to the Indian Dept for certain assistance in regard to the Oak River School at Griswold.

About a year ago the well at the school was condemned. As we were unable at that time to obtain help in digging a new well we have been forced to obtain our water at the agency. We have now obtained an expert to dig a new well and the work is in progress. Our Executive feel however that it is hardly fair to expect Church to assume all the responsibility for the maintenance of the school particularly as we have already expended just over $500.00 in the last year in insulation and new roofing. Re: School, Oak River Reserve, Griswold Agency

Mr. Gow arranged for one of his men to accompany me to Griswold Agency to make a selection of a site for the new school. Attached is a report. You will note preference is given to Location No. 1.

I called on His Lordship, Bishop Thomas, of Brandon, and in searching his records he found that in August of 1908 permission was given to occupy three acres on Section 23 subdivision 15 on the South West corner for the purpose. This letter was signed by J. Lush, Secretary to the Indian Commission. Mr. Young and I made a careful check of the maps of the Reserve. We are convinced that the three acres is a portion of the 40 acres known as Agency property. Therefore, the site desired is legally already Agency property. I might just add that Bishop Thomas and also Canon Norris were very pleased that the school was to be built and stated that if the land belonged to them it would be an order to cooperate with the Indians and that there would be no charge for the land. In view of this information I arranged with Mr. J. Denbow, Brandon, to start next week digging the basement and we expect the work to be completed by September 6th.

In order that there would be no delay in the program, I called at the Lumber Company, Brandon, and the Monarch Lumber Company, only to find that they were both out of shiplap and 2 X 4 dimension. In searching about I found that the Beresford Lumber Company had just received a carload of this material. Mr. Kitchen, the manager, agreed to supply our requirements and I placed an order for the necessary dimension and shiplap. Mr. Young is arranging for the delivery. I was unable to see Mr. Robertson, builder, but Mr. Young will contact him and arrange to have the basement started ready to be extended next week. I also instructed Mr. Young to arrange for the immediate delivery of the gravel. I expect by the end of next week the basement will be dug, the cribbing lumber on the site and also the gravel and nails, with the exception of shingle nails.

Please advise if the Department has arranged for the purchase of the necessary binding wire used in tying the cribwork. Also, have they included in their purchase the iron rods necessary for reinforcement. I understand from Mr. Van Every, Ashdowns, that No. 10 Gauge wire will be available Tuesday, September 2nd. He states that half inch round iron bars 16 feet long for reinforcing are also available. If these have not been included in material already purchased, may I have authority to place the order at once? I would like to point out that the floor joists should be on before starting to pour the cement as the ends will be embedded in the cement wall. Please advise if these have been ordered and if delivery is possible within the next 10 days or two weeks. The above lumber is available at present at the Beresford Lumber Company in Brandon.

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Re: School, Oak River Reserve, Griswold

Further to my letter of August 30th, I wish to state that Mr. Robertson, the contractor, called at my home yesterday to discuss the location and other matters relating to the building. We expect the excavating to be completed by September 6th and plan on building the cribwork the following week. Please advise me the following:

1. Baling Wire for tying cribwork. May this be purchased locally?

2. Reinforcement iron rods available at Ashdowns. May this be purchased?

3. Coal chute must be built in with cribwork. Is this to be a local purchase?

4. Is hot air plant or hot water plant to be used? Recommend hot water. The Department's decision concerning this matter is needed.

5. May coal bin under kitchen be made into a cistern for soft water? The cistern is really essential and I would recommend that the abovementioned space be used for this purpose.

6. Is basement window and frame a complete unit? If so, give size of opening required in the foundation to receive the above frame.

The above information is urgently needed because frames must be built in with the cribwork. Immediate reply by airmail with definite instructions will be greatly appreciated.

Memorandum:

Re:- Griswold Indian Reserve.

On August 28 last, I accompanied Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies at Winnipeg, to the Griswold Indian Reservation to decide upon a location for the proposed Indian School at that point.

Two locations were under consideration - one between the Church buildings and the Agency Office and the other on a flat knoll, somewhat to the rear or west of the existing buildings. In my opinion, the latter location is the more suitable of the two sites in view of good drainage for both building and playground. This site provides for a larger playground and is more isolated from existing buildings yet equally close to the water supply well as is the alternative location. Furthermore, the location decided on will permit the appearance of the building to be set to advantage.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba,
538 Federal Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

I am enclosing herewith an estimate for the repairs necessary to the St. Luke's Mission House in order to place the rooms at present used for the school in proper repairs. You will note the largest item is for the repairs to the floors. These are in quite bad shape. They have had to be oiled in order to keep the dust down, and are badly worn from the desks. The man we had examine them thinks that this is the only way to make them fit for living quarters again.

I would be grateful if you would recommend to the Indian Department that they should undertake this expenditure when the new school has been built, and perhaps you would point out to them that for over twenty-five years they have had the use of these rooms without rent, and we feel, therefore, that we are justified in requesting the Department to return them to us in a good state of repairs.

Yours sincerely,

I. A. Norris,
Secretary-Treasurer.

Re: St. Luke's Mission House
Your letter dated October 3/47

The St. Luke's Mission House is the Church of England residence which has been used for many years to carry on the school work on the Oak River Reserve.

We had no school building and, no doubt, through arrangements made many years ago a part of the Mission House was used for class room purposes. We are now building a school on the Oak River Reserve and when completed it will not then be necessary to use part of the St. Luke's Mission House. It is the rooms used for school purposes that Canon Norris would like repaired and decorated.

Dear Mr. Matthews:

I was very sorry to have been off the Reserve when you called in the summer. I wanted to thank you personally for your help in building us a school here. You will be interested to know that Mr. Robertson is making good progress with the building, and that he is hoping to have it completed in the Spring. I think the Dept. have done well to get the services of such an able and hard working man.

The new school will be ideal for the use of visual educational methods as outlined in the Indian School Bulletins sent to us from time to time by the Dept. I personally am very interested on the use of visual aids, and I am sure the Dept. will be interested to know that I have the use of a projector and screen. Also I am able to have the use of some very good films for the small charge of 25 cents for one showing. This of course will not be any expense for them to meet. All this is not much use unless we have the Hydro or the use of power plant which is established in the Agency. The good news is that the Hydro is now right on the edge of the Reserve - to be accurate just a mile and a quarter to the Mission Compound. I have been in correspondence with the Power Commission in Winnipeg, and they inform me that they would be glad to make the Hydro available to us providing the Dept. of Indian Affairs will be included.

I am wondering if you would be kind enough to show this letter or pass the contents of it to some of the officers in the Department with a request that they will give permission to have the Hydro installed in the school; we of course would be responsible for the Mission House, and other property. If the Department could not see their way clear to do this would they be kind enough
to make available to us the power from the Agency in both school and house.

If we are to realize the ambition of the Department to make the Indian citizen proud of his origin and cultural heritage, education of every type must be utilized in both school and community. Visual aid offers us a splendid opportunity to teach every person on the Reserve the art of modern life, with all its complexities.

With kind regards, and all good wishes,

Yours very sincerely,

Albert E. Kemp.

OUR MOTTO

Jesus Christ the same yesterday, today, and forever. Hebrews 13:8

November 1927

Dear Friends:

During the past few weeks we have been giving a series of addresses on "The Life of a Christian" - its beginnings, resources and characteristics. We have noted that one of the outstanding characteristics of the loyal followers of Jesus Christ should be faithfulness - even unto death, if that should be the alternative of being disloyal to our Lord. How many of us who call ourselves Christians could be sure that our gratitude to God outweighs our fear, so that we are prepared to face not death, but to live devotedly in His service?

So often today the Christian fails to demonstrate his belief in God because he is too worried about his own peculiar problems. Alternatively, the present chaotic state of the world results in his being preoccupied rather than concentrating fully to train himself to work selfishly and pray unceasingly that Christ's Kingdom be established. How many of us would claim similarly that we try to live and order our lives to serve God fully in the fellowship of His Church?

A loyal Christian today, as in the past, must take to heart the words of St. Paul, "Thou therefore endure hardness as a good soldier of Jesus Christ." 2 Timothy 2:3. We know we cannot endure hardness for Christ unless we ask God's help, and unless we are prepared to confirm that prayer by an invincible determination to serve the Son of God who loved us and gave Himself for us. The hour of destiny is at hand and only those who work devotedly and humbly and faithfully can hope to endure unto the end and be saved. May God grant us faith and strength for His service now and at all times in the future.

Yours very sincerely,

Re: Hydro Power - Griswold Agency
Re: File No. 133-3-5 (W.T.) - December 17, 1947.

The enclosed map shows the location of the agency buildings and the road allowance along which the power line runs. The distance from the Agency buildings to the line is about one and a half miles. If power were made available it would likely be used -

1. At the Agency
2. New Day School
3. Church of England House and Church
4. Perhaps the Catholic Mission would also use it in their Church.

I have no idea of the cost of service but, no doubt, the building of the line would cost in the neighborhood of $1000.00 per mile and to wire the Agency buildings would cost perhaps $150.00 each.

The Delco plant now in use at the Agency is too small and badly worn. Installing of the Hydro power would eliminate the purchase of a new lighting plant and batteries and over a period of years might prove less expensive than our present system. I would recommend the change to Hydro be given favourable consideration.

Please return the map when it has served your purpose.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
for Manitoba.
